reviewText:
A unique experience unlike anything else you have played before. Deeply emotional as the story progresses, this feels more like a visual as much as literal poem rather than a pure adventure game.
It is certainly worth trying just for the shake of exploring alternative possibilities in the gaming experience.
My only reservation is the lack of any interaction at all, and I am sure that this plus the shortness will put many people off.
Nonetheless, it remains a path-breaking endeauvour.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
A very interesting psychological journey on a mysterious island, though more of an interactive movie than a game.

Pros:
- Very, very interesting story that is revealed piece by piece as you discover your way through the island.
- Good looking graphics, even by today's standard. Very well designed environment.
- Easy and intuitive controls.
- Though the gameplay is unguided, the way forward often presents itself without too much searching.
- Unique exploration experience. Many different areas to explore, some more out-of-the-way than others and not necessary for completion.

Cons:
- Movement speed is fairly slow. It can feel tedious if you're not really absorbed in the narrative.
- Given the psychological and lonely" nature of the game
date: there's no action whatsoever besides short cutscenes. Those looking for lots of action with their story may want to look elsewhere.\n- Though the graphics are still decent
recommended:
they are beginning to look dated.
- The game has very little replay value as it's a simple narrative story. Completionists may still find extra hours of gameplay looking for all of the different areas to discover and learn more about the narrative.

Overall
hoursPlayed: it's a very interesting story
voteText: though a bit of a one-and-done. I do recommend it
helpfulPercent: especially if it is ever on sale."

reviewText: Dear Esther supposedly transports the player to an island off the West Coast of England. The minimalistic pianomusic and the beautiful graphics stir an eerie feel of being lost in a desolate, deserted environment. As a game, Dear Esther is the sort of interactive medium that transcends the genre. Much like a great David Lynch movie should never be approached the same way one would approach a Star Wars, and is better to be perceived as a piece of art one gets to experience first hand. It hits home on a profound level without feeling the need to comprehend nor to put your finger directly on the heart of the matter. While information is seeping through in a disorderly way, it's only after the first play-through you start to analyse and put things into perspective, There's a reason the final cut scene is followed by a black screen you can only 'escape' from with said key. Still you'll be left with many questions and if you don't want to put hours into figuring it out, I srongly recommend the great youtube analysis on the game's story and events.\n\nFor anyone who might get more thrilled by The Stanley Parable than Assassin's Creed, and prefers a good Kubrick or Lynch over an action packed blockbuster.

reviewText: Inmersive, replayable, different. An experience not for everyone.

reviewText:
I played Dear Esther back when it was a modification, so my play record isn't representative.

Dear Esther, in a nutshell, is an experience. It's not a game, it's not fun, it has zero mechanics and is the true epitome of a walking simulator. So why do I recommend Dear Esther?

Because it is able to invoke emotion through both the little tidbits of story the player encounters and by extremely beautiful and atmospheric scenery.

When I showed this my dad, he told me he didn't get it, but he still spent almost twenty minutes looking at the sea.

reviewText:
In a word, perfection.

It's not a game in the traditional sense, not even close.  But, it is an experience that you won't forget.  You'll hit the screenshot button so many times at first due to the beautiful lighting and atmotsphere.  Eventually, I forgot to take screenshots because the story, the island, and the musical score drew me as I explored the caves.  Drawing your own conclusion is the point" to this "game."

Lighting is incredible and gives the island a dream-like feel.  Narration is spot-on although some later lines were done by a different narrator than you usually hear
date:
which was annoying as their speeds of reading lines are very different.

Note:
Turn up the graphics under Options\Advanced Settings.  The increase in graphic settings didn't seem to effect my fps at all but it definitely made the game look a lot better.

Also
recommended: you may get annoyed with the speed at which you move and the lack of "sprinting" ability.  But remember why you are meant to move slowly: to take it all in."

Difficult to recommend this game because in general, I have little time for indie games at all.

I'm willing to make an exception here, on the proviso that you all understand this isn't strictly speaking a game, rather a mildly interactive short story.   A rather dark story with a gloomy atmosphere.

Regardless, the graphics are impressive for an indy game, running very smoothly at 4K with a respectable set of customisations.    Narration is tasteful and effective.

Atmospherically, the game hits the mark square on.   I won't go too deeply into it, because I recommend the curious should follow the grim story themselves, perhaps late at night with the lights turned down and a comforting glass of red.  The gameplay doesn't go on for long, which is appropriate, it's a novella, but the price isn't particularly high, either.

Thumbs up for hitting the mark, doing something worthwhile, although I should stress this isn't a game in the classic sense, featuring only limited interaction with the environment.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I played Dear Esther back when it was a modification, so my play record isn't representative.

Dear Esther, in a nutshell, is an experience. It's not a game, it's not fun, it has zero mechanics and is the true epitome of a walking simulator. So why do I recommend Dear Esther?

Because it is able to invoke emotion through both the little tidbits of story the player encounters and by extremely beautiful and atmospheric scenery.

When I showed this my dad, he told me he didn't get it, but he still spent almost twenty minutes looking at the sea.

reviewText:
Dear Esther is one of my favorite games, and it's one that is greater than the sum of its parts.

Let me start off with the basics. The game seems boring. You're a guy walking on an island. No enemies, no challenges, no explosions. However, the game makes it work. You're looking for something: Memories? Esther? Salvation? The atmosphere pulls you in, the music coaxes you along. You have this beautifully rendered island ahead of you, composed of somber hues. The red, blinking eye of a radio tower beckons on the horizon. The sun is setting.

I'll admit, my description probably isn't very compelling, but the game is stunningly beautiful, if you give it a chance. The poetic narrative piques your curiosity. The musical score is both ambient and thoughtful and fits the game perfectly. The voice acting is stellar, and even though certain lines do get wordy, it works. Finally, every playthrough is slightly different. Now, that's probably not enough incentive to get you to play through the game again, but I'm glad I did. Something happened in my second playthrough that made it completely worth it. To be honest, it took my breath away.

Here's my bottom line: 90% recommended
Gameplay: 6/10 - There's not much to the gameplay. After all, you are essentially walking through an incredibly well disguised set of hallways. They are really well disguised though.
Story: 8/10 - The minimalist storytelling could get frustrating if you're someone who hates BS. You have to let yourself get swept up by the aesthetics of the moment to really get the most out of it. The bits and pieces" storytelling is neat
date: though. You almost feel like you're walking through the hallways of your mind
recommended: slowly discovering old memories. I gave it an 8 for the artistry.\nGraphics: 9/10 - Some of the most impressive Source engine graphics I've seen yet. They just work.\nSound: 10/10 - The music is definitely one of my favorite parts about the game. It just does its job so well. Additionally
hoursPlayed: the ambient sounds such as the ocean waves and the wind seem very organic. They're very well done.\nActing: 10/10 - Very convincing. A worse actor would not have been able to pull off the artsy dialogue.\nControls: 10/10 - Simple. WADS to move
voteText: mouse to look. It allows you to focus on the game instead of on the buttons.\nGUI/Menus: 10/10 - Unobtrusive
helpfulPercent: elegant. What more can I say?"
votesHelpful: February 14, 2014
votesTotal: true

reviewText: It's amazing that a game in which the only gameplay mechanic is walking can be so engrossing, let alone provide such a deep psychological impact. Your journey will take you across beautiful landscapes that provide a strong sense of solitude, while incredible voice acting will reveal bits of the mysterious story. This game is best played all at once, in one sitting. All of the scenes blend together and prepare you for an ending that will send shivers up your spine. -JJ

reviewText: This game has been sitting in my library for well over a year and today, for some reason or another, I finally decided to sit down and play it. I was very glad that I did. Dear Esther is a short, but extremely well done experience perhaps best compared to a vaguely written, but atmospheric short story. The visuals have retained all of their original beauty and the voice acting tells the story quite well. The pacing and pathing through the environment allowed me to ponder each portion of the story and the environment always made sense with what was happening or what had happened. I enjoyed the ending as well which if you are like me, may cause you to check the internet to make sure that your copy of the game isn't broken. Don't worry. It isn't. The ending is intentional and a smart change to the standard formula. Completely worth the 1 to 1.5 hour playtime and well done enough to deserve your money.

reviewText:
Dear Esther is not a game.
It is interactive Storytelling.
A walkable Poem.
A lucid experience.
A slow unraveling of the narrators mind.
It breaks the limits of what games can be.

I can heartily recommend this game to everyone who wants to try something new - a fresh take on this trusty old entertainment medium.
Just don't walk into this expecting action and plot.
Expect atmosphere thick enough to cut with a knife, stunning visual and maybe even a little bit of confusion.

It is comparable to an art-house film in length and execution. And in the feeling it leaves you with after finishing it.
You might catch yourself days later, thinking about what you experienced on this island.


But without question, it deserves to be played.

reviewText: Dear Esther isn't so much a conventional video game as it is an emotional and aesthetic journey through the limbo of ones mind. In the vein of walking simulator type experiences, Dear Esther keeps you strictly confined to a set path; without the ability to jump, interact with items, and so forth. The visuals are absolutely stunning, the narration absorbing, and the hauntingly beautiful score spectacular. Dear Esther's story unfolds within the protagonists mind, which after a life altering event is left reeling in limbo. The narrative is the progressive element to the story, with the terrain (visuals), reacting and representing concepts accordingly. Dear Esther is a truly beautiful and emotional experience, and although incredibly short, praise must be given to it's clearly very passionate developers.

reviewText: You wander about an uninhabited island, observing and listening to segments of letters the narrator wrote to Esther.  Firstly, this is a story, not a game. It is only slightly interactive, you can not influence the outcome, but you can vary what you hear depending where you wander.  But there is nothing to solve and you can reach the end of the game without visiting all the places.\n\nI really don’t know what to make of this “game”.  It is a sad, haunting tale that is rather depressing.  Certainly, this is not one to cheer you up.  I think overall I have to recommend it, because it's just so well done, but I am afraid I am a happy ending type of person and had I known how haunting this little tale was going to be, I would not have bought it.

reviewText:
It contains beautiful scenery, but more than that it makes you feel like you are actually there. Not in a cheap realism kind of way, but in the way the atmosphere starts to fall over you and draw you in. The storyline winds and fades in and out so that you piece together what you can. It feels like the island itself is somehow responding to your figure slowly making its way across it, changing as you pass. The intricate, sideways comments somehow talk about life and death more directly than most other stories have.

Don't pass this one up. It is beautiful, something you will remember for years to come, and the like of which cannot be experienced anywhere else. You will feel peace. You will feel loneliness. You will feel sadness. And you will feel awe.

Once you have played it for yourself, you are welcome to hear my recording of my thoughts as I passed across the island myself. https://docs.google.com/leaf?id=0B32VpC9sVMpNZWU5MDI1NDEtZDY2Mi00ZmYwLTg5NjQtYWIxMDQzYWMzNGJm

reviewText: Well....... I got this ages ago in a cheap bundle and I don't think I ever would have paid for this knowing what it is.\n\nAs things go it's a fairly pretty game, the sound is rich and it's quite smooth. The storyline is very abstract and basically follows the grief of one man after losing someone he loved. However there is absolutely no interaction within this game, you walk, you can float up in some parts of deep water and you can fall off things. I don't know if this even counts as a game, it's a story where you get to move the camera around. And it's not a very original or even complicated story. If you're looking for a game to play, keep looking, this is an hours worth of walking about on some cliffs listening to some Colin Furth soundalike muttering nonsense to his long dead Esther.

reviewText: Dear Esther in one word: fascinating. It's a fascinating little gaming experiment that just scratches the surface of what I feel could be the most perfect form of storytelling since books. Legit. It really does feel like you're playing through a novel, albeit a very short one, which is its only flaw; it's waaay too short. Despite that, if you enjoyed the design and overall feel of Amnesia, but not the constant fear of death, then this is right up your alley. It's also one of the most visually stunning games I've ever played, even now with games out that factually have better graphics than this, I still think this looks better simply for its incredible visual (and also audio) design.\n\nBut should you buy it for the full $10? No, unless you're a huge poetry, art, and video game enthusiast. Should you buy it on sale for $2.49? Maybe, I did and I think it was worth it, but (if you know me in person) I'd rather just have you play it on my laptop.

reviewText: I recommend this game with big reservations.  It's interesting to play once for the experience, and the cave section is simply beautiful.  However, after all of the praise I heard about it, I was expecting an amazing story and it left me rather underwhelmed.  The walking speed is extremely slow, so rather than replay it to get the alternate dialogue, I simply read the full dialogue blurbs online after I completed it to make sure I read all of them.  The story wasn't bad, but I thought there would be more to it, and the alternate dialogue comments didn't add as much as I thought they would.  I might have felt differently if I had played the game when it came out, but I've played some more recent walking simulators" first which had much more detailed stories so that raised my expectations."

reviewText:
So what can I say about ''Dear Esther''...
I simply wish that more developers would create games or content like this.
Finally a developer who sees that a videogame is art and should be used to create art and not merely cheap thrill enterainment.

This is a very very slowpaced arthouse game. You are not able to jump, run or use objects. You simply walk.
Walk and think, think about life and death, and the strange place in between.
The game leaves you with more questions than answers after you have played through it.
It is a short game, takes only 1.5 hour of your lifetime. There are no archievements and no goals.
You simply reflectt upon life itself.

It is beautiful! Thank you so much for this game and for giving a 75% discount on it.

This is pure love!

reviewText:
a dripstone cave ♥, bioluminescent fungi, phosphorescent moss, crystals, candles in nature, a full moon, a lost stormy beach and grassy hills...

Dear Esther is a spiritual experience. it is visually poetic, profound in form and content, and absolutely magical.
it starts quite plain but with a captivating atmosphere and slowly develops into an almost otherworldly, mystical journey. yes, you do have to do a lot of (slow) walking and at the beginning i wasn't sure if i should continue playing". but i enjoyed the atmosphere (those tasty sounds...) and aesthetics that much that i didn't want to stop exploring; i somehow had the feeling that there was something meaningful to discover. and then there came the entry to that cave...
from this point everything took a totally unexpected course that concluded in a touching and extraordinary experience
date: in every way. and open for a lot of interpretation. the "caves" chapter had an emotionally healing effect on me - i have never experienced something as powerful in a "videogame"...\ntake your time "playing" this
hoursPlayed: maybe even at night. it is pure beauty."

reviewText: Dear Esther in one word: fascinating. It's a fascinating little gaming experiment that just scratches the surface of what I feel could be the most perfect form of storytelling since books. Legit. It really does feel like you're playing through a novel, albeit a very short one, which is its only flaw; it's waaay too short. Despite that, if you enjoyed the design and overall feel of Amnesia, but not the constant fear of death, then this is right up your alley. It's also one of the most visually stunning games I've ever played, even now with games out that factually have better graphics than this, I still think this looks better simply for its incredible visual (and also audio) design.\n\nBut should you buy it for the full $10? No, unless you're a huge poetry, art, and video game enthusiast. Should you buy it on sale for $2.49? Maybe, I did and I think it was worth it, but (if you know me in person) I'd rather just have you play it on my laptop.

reviewText: Well....... I got this ages ago in a cheap bundle and I don't think I ever would have paid for this knowing what it is.\n\nAs things go it's a fairly pretty game, the sound is rich and it's quite smooth. The storyline is very abstract and basically follows the grief of one man after losing someone he loved. However there is absolutely no interaction within this game, you walk, you can float up in some parts of deep water and you can fall off things. I don't know if this even counts as a game, it's a story where you get to move the camera around. And it's not a very original or even complicated story. If you're looking for a game to play, keep looking, this is an hours worth of walking about on some cliffs listening to some Colin Furth soundalike muttering nonsense to his long dead Esther.

reviewText:
Dear Esther is interesting. It's not a game though. You simply walk through the place, looking at the pretty scenery and strange objects whilst listening to a story you have no context for. I've been told that the narration is randomized, so you might hear a different story on subsequent playthroughs.

I suppose you can get really into it, trying to look for all the little details that might hint at clues to some big mystery, but I just didn't care all that much.

This game can be worth it if you pick it up for very cheap, but not full price. It is definitely worth pulling up a YouTube video and checking out Dear Esther's beauty.

reviewText: Dear Esther is the most beautiful game I've seen use the source engine and has done immersion better than any game I have played before it. Although that may be it only lasting all of 40 minutes from start to finish. This isn’t a bad thing as the game does so much in its short time with the colors and amount of detail in each of the four sections throughout the island of Dear Esther giving this sense of wonder and mystery that is well accompanied by the sound design and haunting music all going towards creating this immersive and serene experience.  Its like that moment you have when you're just sitting there looking at or listening to the ocean, a thunder storm or whatever you find relaxing and it just recreates that moment of you have of peace but for an extended period of time, as a “Walking simulator” on this artful island with a story that is, well, forgettable compared to the rest of the game. It doesn’t detract from the experience it supposed to keep it moving forward but for me it was my interest in the island and what was waiting in the next few steps. The presentation of the games graphics and sound design is what made it for me but the story was just an afterthought and I find myself thinking more of the wonderful architecture to Dear Esther rather than the ending or the bits of narration leading up to it.

reviewText: Wow, just wow. This is NOT and I repeat NOT a game of anykind. It is merely an interactive story. You have no memory of who you are (or at least you are given no backgroun info), and you are all alone of an island. Nothing but birds and a lit up tower. This game emotionally appeals to me because while playing it you feel completely alone. As emo as it sounds, its a very nice feeling, you start thinking about life differently. And as CORNY as it sounds I do beleive this game has changed something inside of me. The metaphors in this game are astonishing and egnimic. The final scene of the game (lasts 2 seconds) incredibly makes everything clear. Bravo to this company, thank you for thinking outside the realm of FPS. 10/10 would reccommend to anyone who likes to at leat act intelligent from time to time.

reviewText:
This took me completely by surprise.
It was described to me as a beautiful exploration game set on an island with an interesting narrative.

This is exactly what it is, but it is a whole lot more as well.
The narrative slowly presents the player with a backstory and, to me, this was done in a great way.
At the end, everything is (sort of) clear and the game ends.
After an hour.

You can probably spend twice that if you explore every nook and cranny, but honestly, you shouldn't feel forced to.
I was blown away by this game, though to avoid discussion you might want to label it an experience instead.
Happy I finally gave this a try.

reviewText: I first heard about Dear Esther in late 2011 while browsing the steam Coming Soon" section. The music and poetic narrative of the trailer immediately caught my attention. The description of the game also spoke about "random" elements which greatly intrigued me. However closer to release I became less and less interested. I can't exactly remember why this was
date: maybe another game occupied my thoughts or I wasn't ready to pay the £6.99 for a game that took about 60 minutes to finish. Having only just played and completed Dear Esther for the first time it's a shame I lost interest and didn't purchase when it came out in February 2012.\n\nI won't get into the argument about whether Dear Esther is a game or not
recommended: I want to leave that to angry people on the internet. I will simply talk about what I thought.\n\nFive minutes in
hoursPlayed: the poetic narrative brimming with metaphors (and numerous other poetical devices) tells me I shouldn't follow the narrative too closely. For if I were to try and understand every word I would only get confused and muddled. Each paragraph of narration is somewhat like a standalone poem and only with all of them put together can you actually patch a story together. This works nicely as you can still enjoy the narrative as standalone pieces if you don't understand or miss the previous paragraph.\n\nThat said I'm pretty sure the story of Dear Esther is purposely vague and confusing
voteText: designed partly for the sake of speculation and discussion. For some this could be frustrating as you aren't really supposed to understand anything clearly in the first few play-throughs. That doesn't mean you don't get anything out of the first play-through
helpfulPercent: but Dear Esther is definitely better suited to those very fond of analyzing the deeper meaning of literature and poems. After going through Dear Esther twice many aspects of the story still remain confusing but that's why I like it. There is a great element of mystery about the island
votesHelpful: some details of which I will never understand. I adore that
votesTotal: but like I said earlier
votesFunny: others will find the lack of detail annoying.\n\nWhile there may be a lack of detail in the story
commentsCount: it would be a crime to say the same for the look of Dear Esther. The texture quality is disappointingly low but like a painting
column16: standing back and looking at everything at once is breathtaking. The environment feels eerily natural
column17: there were times I could swear I wasn't looking at a computer screen. The level design is clever too
column18: it gives the illusion of wide open spaces and many possibilities while in reality being very linear. Not to mention the final area sent shivers down my spine continuously for longer than I've ever experienced.\n\nDefinitely not for everyone
column19: but well worth a try if you're interested.\n\nI give Dear Esther a "Looks pretty damn good and brought a tear to my eye
column20: out of 10".\n\nOriginally written for my blog over at: http://d-facegames.blogspot.co.uk/2014/02/my-thunks-dear-esther.html"

reviewText: Dear Esther opens with the beginnings of a letter. As the game's protagonist sets foot onto a deserted island, he starts the game's morose, floridly allegorical narrative with the titular words, Dear Esther". This letter written to Esther contains a rich story whose open-to-interpretation-type narrative makes multiple playthroughs of Dear Esther equally lurid and enlightening
date: despite the game's somewhat tedious gameplay elements. When paired with Dear Esther's ethereal environment
recommended: this narrative creates a deeply mournful and intriguing walking simulator.\n\nThe player's journey up the island begins in the day time
hoursPlayed: beneath ominously gathered clouds and amid rolling hills of withered plantlife. The atmosphere of Dear Esther is filled with tragic elements that add to the story's themes of suffering and grief. During the first half of the journey
voteText: the player will pass by grounded ships and abandoned cottages. As the game continues on
helpfulPercent: the day will grow darker and soon you're plunged into the fantastical darkness of a cave that is illuminated by the rising moon and studded with chemically inspired
votesHelpful: glow-in-the-dark paintings and lines of scripture. The environment of Dear Esther grows stormier and more otherworldly as it approaches the climax of the game.\n\nThe astounding scenery of Dear Esther is paired with frequent pieces of narration from the story's main character. The character's letter to Esther is one filled with metaphors that will depict incredibly abstract images while instilling terrifically tangible emotions in the player. The style of the letter swings between a solemn sadness and a bitter rage
votesTotal: and often the contents of the letter are vague and disjointed—almost as if there are multiple letters and the player is only getting pieces of each one. Each sections of the letter unveils another piece of the story behind your character's climb to the beacon
votesFunny: while leaving enough room for you to speculate about some of the game's more ambiguous plot points.\n\nCompleting more playthroughs of Dear Esther reveals more pieces of the game's shadowy plot; each piece of dialogue the player receives is one of many potential speeches delivered by a supurb voice actor. Untangling the mystery of Dear Esther's story is a slow and thoughtful journey that
commentsCount: with a little bit of patience
column16: could leave you thinking about this game in moments when you least expect it. Dear Esther's literature quality writing and thought-provoking style of gameplay earns it a steady recommendation from me."

reviewText:
How do I even begin to describe Dear Esther?
Well I'd say that it is interactive story telling, but that would be a lie because there is absolutely no interaction at all. For that matter I don't even think it is technically a story either, as it was only a series of letters read aloud in the third person not really containing any cohesive theme. I'd be hard pressed to even call it a video game as it contains not a single gameplay mechanic other than simply walking very slowly on an extremely linear path.
Now all that being said I really enjoyed every minute of the experience, because that is all that it was, just a memorable audio/video experience.
This is simply a stunning piece of motion artwork set to an amazing soudtrack. It was immersive, inflective and above all absolutely gorgeous.
If you are looking for an exciting game keep looking. If you have ever wondered if video games should be considered as an independant art form, BUY THIS GAME.

For what you get I wouldn't pay more than 5$ but it will be a money well spent if you do.

reviewText:
A pretty stroll around an island, intersected at times with semi-random narration vaguely fleshing out your situation (which may change slightly each playthrough).

It is decisively not funny. When you get down to the story, it's rather angsty if not outright depressive. Art at its finest, eh?

I'm somewhat on the fence with this title. In real life I certainly enjoy solitary walks in an unfamiliar area, especially if it's nature oriented rather than industrialized, surrendering to my thoughts. And in video games I often enjoy dropping main storyline to just mess around and explore, if given game lends itself to it at all. But there's always a choice in the matter and other things to do as well along the way, not just sightseeing and meditating.

Whereas Dear Esther is pretty much only the latter. A virtual piece of art, painting/installation with smidgens of verbal narrative, but with zero interaction other than just walking around, pressing forward to push story a bit, see more, and get mind screwed. Even flashlight turns on automatically. It's painting in the medium of video games, but itself is not really a video game at all.

In the end I'd still recommend it, just to experience something different, but if you're not feeling particularly artsy you likely aren't going to enjoy it on any level. However, I am certainly looking forward to reliving it once VR becomes a thing, as this title lends itself perfectly to the whole notion. Really nice scenery porn.

reviewText: When I first bought this game I assumed I was paying $1 for a forgettable horror survival game. Turns out I was very wrong but I was by no means disappointed, at least not when I finished the story. I was upset at first when I discovered what I had bought but I decided to give it a chance all the same. It took me a while to warm up to it but after I did it became one of the top 5 most memorable of my 133 Steam purchases. The soundtrack is so soothing and amazing, it was so good I put it on my iPhone. Combine the music with the amazing storyline and beautiful art style and you have a true masterpiece. I recommend this game to every one of my friends because I truly think anyone can enjoy Dear Esther. Don't think of it as playing a game, think of it as walking through a dream while awake. At least that's what it felt like for me.

reviewText:
It is hard for me to explain exactly how much I disliked this game. For reference I enjoy exploration games and am more than familiar with the world of fine art and have a very high threshold for artsy" things in general. I'm convinced that the only reason why this game got good reviews from so many people is because it's obtuse enough that they figured it must make them seem smart to say they liked it.

The main character moves painfully slowly which wouldn't be an issue if the environment were more enjoyable. The addition of random statements that do not tie in with the environment actually take away from the game. Most of it seems like someone came up with some interesting looking areas and some cryptic statements and decided that throwing them together at random would be a lovely idea for a game. Every so often the statements will line up with the environment and there's a moment of clarity about what is going on. Unfortunately those moments of clarity were not interesting enough to make me care in the slightest what was going on.

I think I would have enjoyed this slightly more if no one had tried to tell me it was good first. That and if the bits of dialogue were not randomized in an attempt to make it different or if they were written so that it pieced together better regardless of order. There are ways of making your audience work that are effective and enjoyable
date: this game doesn't use any of them."

reviewText:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DlNEYBirnXQ

Opening with your in front of the Lighthouse with your character delivering a soliloquy, after which you are left to explore your surroundings. There are no objective markers, no text prompts, no intrusive and hideous HUD to obscure your view of the world. Exploring the nooks and crannies of the surrounding area occasionally prompts random statements from your character. In these letters are few of the Island's former inhabitants are referenced repeatedly. There are also several themes that emerge from these excerpts and astute players will notice those themes reflected in the environment. A glowing red beacon on top of a radio tower is almost always present and, like a moth to a flame, is compels you to seek it out. Paths split and merge around the island and it's easy to find your way forward.

This set up wouldn't be engrossing for very long if it wasn't for the visuals. Dear Ester benefits from an excellent graphical presentation and art direction. Textures are rich, dust picks up, leaves blow around, the foliage is dense, and landmarks dot an otherwise open landscape. Warm candle glow contrasts with cool night skies and somehow Dear Esther manages to make caves, often the most drab environments found in games, rather breath taking. Rock walls are scrawled on with luminescent goo, and the rocks form awesome structures with stalactites and stalagmites jutting from the bedrock forming nefarious teeth. Rivers flow through the cave's interior terminating in grand waterfalls. It is perhaps here that the game's setting can be most clearly seen as a metaphor.

To deride Dear Esther for it's lack of actual gameplay is to remain oblivious to it's excellent adaptation of literary devices to tell a simple interactive story. It's a story that places you not just in the shoes of the protagonist but in his mind and soul. Its an introspective tale which is remarkably rare for a video game. To discuss any more of the plot would undermine the experience and the mystery. Allegory, allusions and metaphors are all present. Dear Esther explores new territory for narrative in an interactive media. With it's lack of a defined structure and a devilish desire not to be too explicit with its plot points Dear Esther's yarn will displease some an accusations of pretension will likely ensue.

There have been games in the past with exquisite narratives and there have been games that have extraordinary gameplay and mechanics. The biggest challenge is getting these two aspects of a game to work together harmoniously—to have game mechanics that fit into narrative themes. Mechanics and gameplay elements that reflect the subtext of the narrative itself. In many games story and gameplay exist in almost separate bubbles. Actual narrative often bookends levels and takes a backseat while the player controls their character. It's an antiquated formula that only a handful of games seem to have shaken.

The way The Chinese Room engages the player without traditional mechanics is through simple exploration. By making discoveries in the world you are treated to a bit of exposition. Symbols, diagrams, and writings can be found in the world to reflect elements of the exposition. A book or film could never deliver the level of immersion that Dear Esther offers. The experience only works because the player can choose to see or not to see things in the environment. The ability for the player to set the pace of the story and be given the opportunity to discover the details makes Dear Esther work.

Dear Esther has had a remarkable journey from Half Life 2 mod to independent release. It's an exercise in adapting literary conventions to an interactive experience and it's an exercise worth taking part in. The excellent soundtrack and visuals hold your attention while the plot takes shape. The conclusions will stick with you long after the hour and a half it takes to see it through and it's likely that you will want to revisit Dear Esther to soak in it's finer points.

reviewText:
A game taking place on a deserted, dismal Hebridean island, housing a peculiar, unobtrusive wandering, promptly sounds like the concept of an experiment. Given the complete absence of interaction between the player and the game, as the nameless player's protagonist without visual identification strolls through the mist, while the release of random sound recordings of letters read out loud to a woman named Esther, it is indeed in fact an experiment. The identity of the woman is unclear, as is the relationship between the two of you; however, as you progress through the windblown beaches, the moors, the deep caves as well as the lighthouse - towards the peak of the island - detached diary notes depict the outlines of a tragic accident, and a ghostly tale appears.

The story of Dear Esther is utterly obscure and abstract. Cryptic biblical quotation is occasionally displayed on the surroundings, and out of the sound recordings the history of the island surface, along with the hints of a freeway, the disclosure of a fatal car crash, and three personalities; a shepherd with syphilis, an explorer whose infected wounds made him mad, and a broken man with guilt involving the mentioned car accident. However, the dividing line between them becomes blurred, and depending on how you interpret the course of the events, they may ultimately not be three different individuals.

Considering the game (or not-game) strongly emphasizes the suggestive approach, excluding any specific details and concrete clues, I hardly see it as a puzzle to be pieced together. Through the looking glass, I believe Dear Esther is neither a search for an answer, nor even for a meaning, but an experiment with the senses and emotions. It is a lonely, guilt-stricken journey through morbidly beautiful emptiness; an emotive smorgasbord of sight, sound, implication and metaphor, aimed to generate a feeling of purposeful despair. The world is quiet, uneventful and subdued, the atmosphere isolated and melancholic, and one chapter in particular - namely the cave - might be the most strikingly beautiful achievement ever presented on a monitor.

The only interaction Dear Esther provides is to look at it, to experience it. To react to what my own mind evokes in response by the emotional implications and occurring subtlety, not to on-screen prompts or physical reflexes. It is a lonely, slow 90-minute walk of purgatory dealing with sorrow, loss, shame, faith and sickness, but also love, hope and atonement. One look at the washed-out hillside, the empty and devastated houses, the constant twinkle of a distant radio mast, and the harrowingly lack of any other life whatsoever (except an eerie silhouette along the horizon and the occasional bird) tells me, however, almost all I need to know; the night slowly falls, and it falls with a sinister reason. The approaching call to that perceptible, mystery mast is inevitable.

It is a simulator of subconscious introspection that pretty much can be associated with walking along an empty road along the coast at night and where your mind went at that time. But at the end of the day, Dear Esther doesn't need to tell me anything, nor does it really attempt to, despite the minimalistic events that is self-evident enough through implication alone; it only needs to make me feel something, and indeed it does. The meaning I create for myself, both early on and during the resolution, is more than that could ever be - yet it is nothing concrete or even describable. The devoid of clarity is strangely enough satisfying.

Robert Briscoe's uncompromising game design combined with the dark, sensitive tones of composer Jessica Curry's rewritten soundtrack of haunting strings and piano, the island's quiet ambience and underlying emotional depth has the qualifications to profundly affecting the player. Game scientist and lecturer Dan Pinchbeck, who originally created the game back in 2008, has proved that violence and puzzles and logic are not necessarily required. The narrative alone can be just as essential.

8.5 / 10

reviewText:
It's been 6 months since I played this game. 6 bloody months and I couldn't stop thinking about how awful this game was; every time I think about it I feel so bad for the time I wasted on it. The main reason I'm writing this review is because every now and then I think about this game and I lose my hope in life even yesterday when I went to sleep It came into my mind like when a child start thinking about the monster who lives in the closet so I must get it out of my system and express how I feel about it.
Firs of all there are two kinds of bad games: The first kind is when you discover that the game is bad after 5 minutes of playing it like Uriel's Chasm . The second kind (which is the worst) is when the game keeps feeding you hope that it'll be better if you played it just a little bit more but you eventually discover that its crappy like Dear Esther.
This game doesn't have a real good graphics like The Vanishing Of Ethan Carter and you only need WASD to move really really slow and you can't sprint which is really stupid knowing that there are plenty of space to walk through for example you reach a crossroad and you decide to take the left road and after 5 minutes of walking and listening to stupid narration you reach a dead end and you have to get back exactly from where you came but without the narration.
I payed 2.99$ for it which is the minimum amount of money the lazy developers should pay people to play this game in fact this game should be used for torturing terrorists and even if you did that and they managed to stay alive until they finish the game you will feel sorry for them for playing it and give them a hug.
At the end I'd like to say that I have never gave a game a bad review before but Dear Esther is way worse than just bad; it's the worst game I've ever played and it is the reason why I wish that one day steam users can permanently delete a game from their account and get rid of the shame of playing it. This game has left a scar in me that needs a long time to heal it's a shame on indie games and always will be and I would never forgive myself for playing it for the end.
For the developers: I hate you and I wish you bad luck and I hope that you'll never see success in the gaming industry

reviewText:
Very boring, a true walking simulator.

You can do nothing but walk and walk; there are no enigmas or riddles (I expected that), and basically you walk on a closed and forced path that eventually leads you to the end. The plot is pretty sad and surely not entertaining, even though the voice acting is as remarkable as the visuals and the music.

I would recommend it to... none. There are games that try to create emotions, as Dear Esther does, without being this dramatic, sad and generally unappealing.

I wish there was more other than the melancholic voice of a hopeless character in this game; I reached the end in an hour, and I didn't enjoy it. The replayability is absent, except of course if you want to go through the game again.

Graphic: 7/10
Sound: 8/10
Gameplay: 4/10
Longevity: 2/10

Final Rating: 4/10

Dear Esther fails hard bringing emotions and a fresh breath among the first person adventures. Recommended only to game reviewers and developers. Definitely boring and not entertaining for the gamers.

reviewText:
Edit: Alright, so I finished it, and it's much more interesting toward the end. The game gets off to an extremely slow start, but find your way around, get off the beach areas, and endure 'til later, and your experience will greatly improve. There's a lot more to see once you're off the beach. I wouldn't pay full price for this game, but if exploring games are your thing, you could give this a try.

---------------------------

One hour into the game:
I guess it's pretty, if desolate, and the narrator has some poetic lines (once in a while, when you find where you're supposed to go), but the majority of my experience so far as been... frankly, uncomfortable. I find myself wishing that you could move faster instead of walking so painfully slowly, and it's extremely off-putting that you can't jump or climb. At all. At this point I feel like I'd jump for joy if I could just get to the top of this mountain. If you get lost easily like me, it's going to be difficult in the beginning. There's a lot of backtracking, and I'm not quite sure where to go, ever. The narrator is completely unhelpful when you're trying to figure out where to go next, and this self-guided tour is starting to feel pretty oppressive. I find myself desperately wanting to leave this abandoned beach.

First-person exploration games are probably not for me, but if they're your cup of tea, it might be worthwhile to try this. If you're got an eye for detail and enjoy analyzing your environment to help supplement/piece together a storyline, maybe this is for you. As for me, I think I need more direction and structure in my games...

reviewText: Dear Esther is a somber promenade in the chronicle of a morbid lover -- an opaque, emotional, restless, slightly fatalistic fever dream, if fever dreams were ever digitized. It's not a videogame; there is no interaction, save for the narrator's cues. It's more of a semi-cinematic, semi-literary, three-dimensional painting for the player to wander semi-aimlessly. If you dispense with any notion of depth and allow yourself to be absorbed in the beautiful world (beyond question, the best-looking application of the Source engine to-date), Dear Esther provides a truly unique experience for the jaded appetite.

reviewText:
Ever noticed how, very occasionally, you will play a game, listen to a piece of music, watch a movie or whatever, and you know, as soon as you've finished that it will stay with you for a long time?
I'm getting that right now.

I've just played through Dear Esther twice and I find it to be time and money VERY well spent.
This is not a game in the conventional sense.
If your fix is usually space marines shooting aliens, this might not be for you. It is very unorthodox.

It has no enemies, no other characters, no items, no object interaction at all. All you do is walk and explore as the back story unfolds through often dreamy monologues.
But therein lies its strength. It really does try something different, and it pays off.

It really is beautiful. It's a couple of years old now, but if you crank the settings up to full it really shines. This is due in large part to the actual art direction and creation of the island setting. It looks very natural with no copy and paste going on and it all takes place in dusk or night time so it looks moody and washed out.
Seriously, take time to look around at the scenery.

The sound is completely perfect and enhances the experience no-end.
The musical score is haunting and perfectly timed to coincide with epic scenery or other happenings. The narrator (the only voice in the 'game') does an excellent job as well.

It's a strange thing that a game in which you do so little can have such an impact, but that really is the case for me.
This game is as beautiful/haunting/mysterious as it is unorthodox.
It won't be for everyone, but if you are open to something different, put those headphones on, turn out the lights and go for a walk :-)

reviewText: Dear Esther is not a game. It is an interactive experience. It's also quite depressing and - despite some beautiful visuals - quite dull.\n\nMore of an art experiment, Dear Esther" has you following in the footsteps of a would-be suicide as he mournfully regrets the loss of his deceased wife. It's neat how the game randomly picks parts of the narrative to play  to you as you wander the moors; no run through will get exactly the same experience. Unfortunately
date: that narrative is dry and uninteresting. The moors are pretty but there's nothing to do there except marvel at the graphics. And the end is entirely predictable.\n\nFrankly
recommended: I'd have been better off just looking at the screenshots.\n"

reviewText:
Now this is art. It's a beautiful 'game', an adventure, where all you do is walk around, with a bit of exploring. At certain points in this adventure a narrator will try to tell you (bits of) a story. A cryptic one, mind you. In the end its interpretation is up you, the player. Some of the stories are random, meaning you might get a different one the next time you play. It's a short story, and it will take about 1-2 hours to 'complete', but, in my opinion, it's worth it. There's so much atmosphere in it, it's beautiful. Who would've thought the Source engine could still produce these kind of graphics ? It's breathtakingly beautiful. The little music there is is also perfect.
The only little glitch I found was occasionally getting stuck in the environment, but it's not at all gamebreaking.
And even though the price is steep for such a short experience, I would still gladly recommend it.

[Rating: 87/100]

reviewText:
Heart-breakingly, profoundly and joyously beautiful. I have never seen a game that has been created so lovingly and with dedication and precision as this. It is truly an experience that I've never had before while sat in front of my computer. The atmosphere and ambience is incredibly strong and you'll find yourself simply stopping and staring in wonder.

However, you won't find yourself stopping that much because you are already walking incredibly slowly and, wonderous and awesome as it is, you'll be bored pretty quick and be VERY glad when you reach the end. But, when you reach the end, you'll appreciate the experience you just had.

Think of it as a condensed Lord of the Rings - you had to see it, you were excited by it, you slowly had to admit as you were watching that it drags on and on and isn't actually very good - but when you finish, you are grateful that you watched it.

I would HIGHLY recommend this program as an experience - I enjoyed and was amazed by it. But I'm 99% sure I will never load it up again - just as I'm sure I'll never watch Lord of the Rings again.

reviewText:
Dear Esther is a first-person ghost story. Rather than traditional game-play the focus here is on exploration, uncovering the mystery of a lonely island, of who you are and why you are here. Fragments of story are randomly uncovered when exploring the various locations of the island, making every each journey a unique experience.

Dear Esther is an auditory and visual experience that interweaves a consuming narrative and array of emotions. The game's actual value must not be solely based upon its gameplay length, but rather on the random elements and new secrets discovered through multiple playthroughs. Those that brave the journey into the narrative and world of Dear Esther will discover an experience that few games have been available to accomplish in years. Highly recommended.

Dear Esther completely changes the language in which we communicate with a videogame; it is an interactive experience whose notion of interactivity demands much more from the players than they are used to.

Dear Esther is a peculiar game. With its beautiful landscapes and script, some people could find it a great experience, others could hate the lack of interaction and the plain gameplay. One of the most haunting and well-executed titles of this or any other generation.

Mysterious, poetical and full of atmosphere – Dear Esther is as magical as a short story from Ray Bradbury. The creative way of storytelling fascinated me from the very first moment.

reviewText:
Dear Eshter.
It is my regret that I am incapable of writing anything nearly as beautiful as the letters meant for Esther. Letters stained in brilliant lines by the love poured over them from a man in grief.
Dear Esther is a very slow burning story that many people would easily find to be dreadfully boring. But in the same length of time in which you could watch a feature length film, you can simply wander through overgrown paths on an island and traverse the gorgeous caves beneath. The scenery is stunning but empty except for some cryptic clues; equally as cryptic as the haunting narration that accompanies them.
Rarely have I cared so much to understand an allegorical story. and never have I come out of one with at least three distinct theories as to its meaning, narrative, past, and conclusion. However, the most unfortunate aspect of trying to delve in to the deepest parts of the story is the inevitable realization that, unknowable details aside, the circumstances of the events are not very interesting; they just tug at a few emotional strings.
One of the few things that sets Dear Esther apart from Proteus is the fact that there is a story and there are actually some things on the deserted island that garner attention.

reviewText: In this touching NPR walkman museum audio visual coordinated headphone tour you will learn about the wonderful life of a bird with opposable thumbs who occasionally uses a flashlight to shine light on subjects like kidney stones, goats, and syphilis. Truely touching, I will never be the same again.\n\nCan I recommend it, no. But If you want a good laugh because of ridiculous dialogue that changes each time you play all while walking though beautiful landscapes and wallpaper art, give it a shot. It wouldn't hurt. Just hearing the Fartsy Poetic Dialouge made me laugh and cringe at the same time. I have played through this game twice and have no clue what it's about.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game, but it just fell short of my expectation.  I was hoping that it would more of an emotional type of game, but I just didn't feel anything there.  I personally thought that I'm more of a sensitive type of person, that I can be emotional if I let myself to be.  Perhaps my heart was made of stone the day I played this game(or maybe I should have played the game with lights off,  and with some wine and scented candles, then maybe...just maybe...I might like this game.)

I can tell that the developer focused all the effort in the writing/narration, game environment and the presentation of the game.  I admit that the writing of it is beautiful, combined with as beautiful game environment. However, I felt that the game is trying too hard to be poetic or artistic.  And in my humble opinion, I think it was a bit too pretentious.  In fact, I don't think I have play any other game that actually made me feel this way.

One of the other things that I didn't like about this game is that there is no instant or manual save option. I understand that this type of game is best to be played in one sitting, but it is still nice to have that option.  The first time I played this game, I played about 20 minutes. I got to a different area in the game, it was after the loading screen; and I had to stop playing the game, thought that it had auto-save. But it didn't auto-save, so I had to play the game from the beginning again.  So the next and last time I played this game, I had this constant unpleasant feeling behind the back of my mind, wondering when this game is going to end, and hoping that it would end sooner; because I sure don't feel like starting the game all over again.

There are only a few things that I like about this game.  I like the atmosphere of the game; I enjoyed walking around the seaside, cave...etc.  Some people complained about the walking speed being too slow, but I thought that the speed is just fine for me. I also like the soundtrack, suits the game very well.  For a first person POV game, it was a good thing that they  actually added controller support, that's another minor thing that I appreciate.

All I can say is that this game is still a good enough experience for me.  So, l won't say that I want that couple hours of my life back; but overall, I won't say that I recommend this to everyone.

reviewText: Absolutely incredible... Assuming you can appreciate a more 'artistic' take on gaming. In truth there isn't much gaming here, it is more like an interactive movie... Or book. The game is a slow walk around a gorgeous island while an elequent, but verbose, narator reads from letters he will never send to Esther. The graphics are amazing (no teslation or anything but very high resolution textures and advanced lighting and reflection). The island is rendered beautifully and the story is interesting enough to hold your attention. The biggest down side is that I 'beat the game' in a little over an hour. I am pretty cheap, I buy almost everything on sale in Steam and somehow this was worth it at $10 for 1 hour.

reviewText:
Dear Eshter.
It is my regret that I am incapable of writing anything nearly as beautiful as the letters meant for Esther. Letters stained in brilliant lines by the love poured over them from a man in grief.
Dear Esther is a very slow burning story that many people would easily find to be dreadfully boring. But in the same length of time in which you could watch a feature length film, you can simply wander through overgrown paths on an island and traverse the gorgeous caves beneath. The scenery is stunning but empty except for some cryptic clues; equally as cryptic as the haunting narration that accompanies them.
Rarely have I cared so much to understand an allegorical story. and never have I come out of one with at least three distinct theories as to its meaning, narrative, past, and conclusion. However, the most unfortunate aspect of trying to delve in to the deepest parts of the story is the inevitable realization that, unknowable details aside, the circumstances of the events are not very interesting; they just tug at a few emotional strings.
One of the few things that sets Dear Esther apart from Proteus is the fact that there is a story and there are actually some things on the deserted island that garner attention.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: In Dear Esther, the player is immersed into the perspective of an unidentified protagonist on a seemingly abandoned and decaying island. What may seem as an initially non-linear game turns out to be a compelling narrative where the player must piece together the identity of the protagonist and his purpose on the island. Dear Esther, is not a conventional game where the player actively meets goals and exercises decisons, but rather a beautiful trek through the life of a man whose life is shattered for reasons unknown. Hauntingly mystifying and possessing cinematic qualities galore, Dear Esther is highly recommended to those interested not only in the conventions of storytelling but innovative game design as well...

reviewText:
Dear Esther
Where do I start? This has been the most intriguing, emotionally-tying games since Journey by ThatGameCompany (PS3-exclusive). The soundtrack is mesmirizing, as well as the scenery. The story...though perhaps touching on cliches, is one of deep heartache. You come to empathize with the narrator. And as you know, empathizing with a game character can only lead to intense emotional response.

Even though it's short, it is still worth playing. There are all sorts of secrets to explore once you've done the initial run-through.

reviewText: A pathetic attempt at profundity and a complete waste of time. To be clear, I love experiemental, explorative, and narrative games. Gone Home is great, I even appreciate The Graveyard. But Dear Esther is like someone got really high, read ten pages of Melville, and tried to write a novel in his style. When he looked and realized it was only two pages long, he decided to make it seem longer by dispersing two paragraphs at a time while you walk across a hill. The characters are nothing more than names, there is no emotion to speak of, and the mystery is answered by another mystery- why you even played the game at all. It is utterly without substance or redeeming value of any sort.

reviewText: Not so much an interactive game as an exploration into tragedy, loss and grief told through one man's journey across a desolate, Hebridean island. Dear Esther is more like a form of slow and very intentional interactive art, akin to viewing a captivating painting where you're suddenly allowed to step inside the frame and experience the scene in its entirity as you desire rather than be confined to just one perspective. The story is conveyed in fractured pieces of spoken memory of old letters - or possible delusion - and left to the player to construct for themselves as different readings are presented at specific points along your journey, the semi-random nature of these readings meaning multiple playthroughs are required for them to be fully imparted to you. Touching and visually captivating in equal measure, Dear Esther is a brief yet nonetheless poignant example of how the medium of gaming is more than capable of producing beautiful and contemplative works that can provoke great emotion, backed by a strong musical score setting the perfect wistful tones to accompany the bleak isolation and inward reflection of the journey. If you have the interest and willingness to explore such things then this will reward you greatly.

reviewText:
Dear Esther is a game of art and emotion driving exp. The game may not have any goals, other than walking around and figuring out what is going on; but the game takes you on a journey of wonder. The game has simple controls, you either walk using the arrow keys or WASD keys, and the mouse to look around. You can click the mouse button to zoom in on detail but other than that, that is it in controls.

There are 4 levels in this game, and each level is a story. Everytime you play the game, more random storylines are told, so the replayability is high. This game could be called a narrative game. It is a great work of art via audio and visuals. Each level is done so beautifully it takes your breathe away. I love just playing the game slowly, listening to the audio and enjoying my time in the world.

This game might not be for everyone, because all you do is walk, listen, and enjoy at your own pace, but it is fun and the art talent is very good in this game. It is by far my favorite game.

reviewText:
Dear Esther is more of an experience than a game.  And that experience is one where you will need to peel the onion to see what lurks below the surface.  The experience is rich in layers of perception and one which varies from player to player and even for the same player, if he or she repeats any of the chapters of Dear Esther.

Usually in a game we would expect some combination of:

* A set of rules
* Interactions with NPC's or other players
* The ability to interact with the environment; e.g. pick up stuff, move things, shoot things, etc.
* Quests
* Achievements
* In-Game Rewards

You won't find any of that in Dear Esther, at least not in the way you might expect, if at all.  Rather in Dear Esther you can only move along some fairly well defined paths using directional controls.  With a controller, the left stick is directional for  movement and the right stick is directional for view.  That's it. You can't pick up an item to examine it.  There is no interaction with any other player or any NPC's.  The only quest would be your exploration of the location following a linear path where certain points trigger narrator readings of text  in what is presumably meant to be letters to Esther, who may or not be real and who you never meet and who you suspect is dead, if she lived at all.

So if this isn't a game, what kind of gamer would want to fire up Dear Esther and wander around to see what there is to offer in the virtual environment?   I suspect that there isn't any one personality type that one would have to be to enjoy this, but it would appeal most to a person given to introspection, who likes to patiently collect clues and peel them away to try to uncover the real story and not be particularly upset, if the answer is that there isn't necessarily an answer or that there are many answers that all may have some degree of validity.  In other words it is a mind game, if it is a game at all.  And one where you are left to try to discern meaning amid chaos and confusion in an imperfect world where your questions are not always answered.

The experience runs between an hour and half to twelve hours depending on how fast you proceed and whether or not you go back to replay and see what you missed.  And yes, you can miss a great deal the first time through - either because it wasn't there in the first place or because you were tuned in to find it.  For example, there are as many as ten ghostly appearances and you may only see one or two the first time through Dear Esther.   I say this based on what I perceived in my playthrough and what others have reported in their playthrough(s).

The Celtic music is absolutely haunting and makes the game superb.  If you don't get goosebumps, you're not paying attention.  The visuals are stunning and the narrative readings are full of emotion and maybe more.  All of it works together to cause you to feel a lot of emotion while causing you to start asking more and more questions about what it is that you are experiencing.

So by now you are probably saying, What the heck kind of review is this?  You are talking in circles and driving me nuts."  If so
date: I understand.  The answer is that this really isn't a game in the traditional sense and instead an experience where you are given clues in the environment and narration to piece together after which you are expected to use a healthy dose of imagination
hoursPlayed:
and deductive reasoning to shape your own idea of what the story really is.

In truth of it is that Dear Esther is one of those things where you may get more out of it by discussing it with friends and other players than by just playing it through.

If you decide to have a run at Dear Esther
voteText:
you might be well advised to constantly ask:

*  Is what I'm perceiving real?

*  Is there symbolism here?

*  Is this place real or imaginary; e.g.
helpfulPercent: is this a memory
votesHelpful: a dream
votesTotal: some device
votesFunny: a real location
commentsCount: or some combination?\n\n*  Are the names of people given in the narration separate real individuals
column16: creations of a fractured mind
column17: representations of something other than a person
column18: etc.\n\nIn the end you may ask is this a simple sad story of withdrawl from the world and madness following the death of a loved one
column19:
or something entirely different?

At this point I must apologize for a review that has taken longer to write than it took to run through Dear Esther itself.  So now it is probably time to close with a few thoughts.

Dear Esther got me to put my thinking cap on and see many possibilities
column20: which is sometimes a good thing.  And perhaps that's the point of Dear Esther to get people to examine perception and meaning.  I suspect that Dear Esther's value is more in the discussion than in the playing.\n\nIf you do play Dear Esther all the way through and come out with more questions
column21: than answers

reviewText: This game is based on a mod that I have not played, so for the purposes of this review it will not be considered.\n\nWhile it's easy to criticize the gameplay (a word that hardely applies to this game) or the linearity of Dear Esther, this completely ignores the focus of this game, which is story telling and exploring. While the exploration is somewhat limited and definitely pre-determined, the atmosphere and visuals are so well done this hardly matters. During the game, the player finds himself so captivated by the contrasting bleakness and vibrance of the world and it's atmosphere, that he finds his every action and every thought hinged on the next line from the narrator or the next scene, dissolving away the percieved limitations which are so often used to criticize this game. If you are looking to get more out of your game experience, a step above the typical shoot-kill-earn point" mechanics that are so popular in today's games
date: I'd recommend Dear Esther. Otherwise your better off with one of the more popular games which stimulate neither the mind nor the imagination."

reviewText:
Finally got around to playing this. I recommend playing through without the subtitles unless you really don't understand his accent. The text kept breaking the immersion for me. Visually very beautiful, and I recommend using some nice headphones and turning the lights down to get the full effect. Controls were very simple move, look, and zoom. I spent a little over an hour walking around till the end just taking everything in.

Overall it was very interesting. I enjoyed the branching directions which always left me wondering if I should go back because I had missed something. There were also some various strange situations that gave me the impression that I was not alone. I kind of had an idea of what might happen at the end as the story felt it was shifting in tone but it still left things up in the air for the player to decide what the actual meaning was.

Definitely recommend playing it once if you ever get a chance and have about an hour to kill.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I finished this game about ten minutes ago. My thoughts are as follows:

If I sailed in a paper boat without a bottom, then I am further your spinnaker dangling on a toothpick, destined to flap about and try not to lose hold. These twin vapor trails, these white lines which we have together etched into the lonely cliff-face may be our final signatures, our epitaphs as at least I soar into this nothingness. Anywhere away from Donnelly, anywhere away from Jakobson, and from Damascus, and from even more I may one day part. If this paper boat is my galleon, then let fate be our drunken captain and tragedy be our map.

Intimate, poignant, and psychologically intense, Dear Esther is a gem of polished, shining facets. You'll laugh, you'll gasp and cry. You'll become claustrophobic and develop an unmatched love for candles. You'll take risks, and then you'll cleverly un-take them as needed. The ending left my jaw dropped and my hands floundering for tissues. Wonderful way to spend a rainy night.

Tip: I entered this game unfamiliar with the controls. Learn to swim early, and learn what not to swim in. Explore everything twice and never halt your thinking.

reviewText: I wasn't expecting a action game or anything when I got this game; It's a story game. That's it. reviewText: In this touching NPR walkman museum audio visual coordinated headphone tour you will learn about the wonderful life of a bird with opposable thumbs who occasionally uses a flashlight to shine light on subjects like kidney stones, goats, and syphilis. Truely touching, I will never be the same again.\n\nCan I recommend it, no. But If you want a good laugh because of ridiculous dialogue that changes each time you play all while walking though beautiful landscapes and wallpaper art, give it a shot. It wouldn't hurt. Just hearing the Fartsy Poetic Dialouge made me laugh and cringe at the same time. I have played through this game twice and have no clue what it's about.

reviewText:
Dear Eshter.
It is my regret that I am incapable of writing anything nearly as beautiful as the letters meant for Esther. Letters stained in brilliant lines by the love poured over them from a man in grief.
Dear Esther is a very slow burning story that many people would easily find to be dreadfully boring. But in the same length of time in which you could watch a feature length film, you can simply wander through overgrown paths on an island and traverse the gorgeous caves beneath. The scenery is stunning but empty except for some cryptic clues; equally as cryptic as the haunting narration that accompanies them.
Rarely have I cared so much to understand an allegorical story. and never have I come out of one with at least three distinct theories as to its meaning, narrative, past, and conclusion. However, the most unfortunate aspect of trying to delve in to the deepest parts of the story is the inevitable realization that, unknowable details aside, the circumstances of the events are not very interesting; they just tug at a few emotional strings.
One of the few things that sets Dear Esther apart from Proteus is the fact that there is a story and there are actually some things on the deserted island that garner attention.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: In Dear Esther, the player is immersed into the perspective of an unidentified protagonist on a seemingly abandoned and decaying island. What may seem as an initially non-linear game turns out to be a compelling narrative where the player must piece together the identity of the protagonist and his purpose on the island. Dear Esther, is not a conventional game where the player actively meets goals and exercises decisons, but rather a beautiful trek through the life of a man whose life is shattered for reasons unknown. Hauntingly mystifying and possessing cinematic qualities galore, Dear Esther is highly recommended to those interested not only in the conventions of storytelling but innovative game design as well...

reviewText:
Dear Esther
Where do I start? This has been the most intriguing, emotionally-tying games since Journey by ThatGameCompany (PS3-exclusive). The soundtrack is mesmirizing, as well as the scenery. The story...though perhaps touching on cliches, is one of deep heartache. You come to empathize with the narrator. And as you know, empathizing with a game character can only lead to intense emotional response.

Even though it's short, it is still worth playing. There are all sorts of secrets to explore once you've done the initial run-through.

reviewText:
Dear Esther is a first-person ghost story. Rather than traditional game-play the focus here is on exploration, uncovering the mystery of a lonely island, of who you are and why you are here. Fragments of story are randomly uncovered when exploring the various locations of the island, making every each journey a unique experience.

Dear Esther is an auditory and visual experience that interweaves a consuming narrative and array of emotions. The game's actual value must not be solely based upon its gameplay length, but rather on the random elements and new secrets discovered through multiple playthroughs. Those that brave the journey into the narrative and world of Dear Esther will discover an experience that few games have been available to accomplish in years. Highly recommended.

Dear Esther completely changes the language in which we communicate with a videogame; it is an interactive experience whose notion of interactivity demands much more from the players than they are used to.

Dear Esther is a peculiar game. With its beautiful landscapes and script, some people could find it a great experience, others could hate the lack of interaction and the plain gameplay. One of the most haunting and well-executed titles of this or any other generation.

Mysterious, poetical and full of atmosphere – Dear Esther is as magical as a short story from Ray Bradbury. The creative way of storytelling fascinated me from the very first moment.

Very enjoyable and comforting."

reviewText: This is a beautiful game that keeps you thinking and wondering till the end, as you explore the island you learn about a story about a couple and their journey together. There is no shooting or puzzles be had, there is nothing that is really a challenge in this game, all you do is explore and enjoy the scenery that is around you. The graphics and physics of the plants and movement of the water is amazing and very well done. The music is relaxing and peaceful to listen to. The story is captivation and makes you want to know more. The game of Dear Esther has a very nice pace to it. It is calming and doesn't take long at all to beat. I highly recommend this gem to anyone who wants a change of pace and wants to just walk around and look at things while hearing a story. This is a great game and I've really enjoyed it from beginning to end.

reviewText:
Boring.

The game looks gorgeous, but that's it.

The gameplay (or lack of) is just walking around. No sprinting or running, just walking. Wanna move faster? You can't (unless you use cheats). This, in fact, punishes exploring the environment, because going away from the path, or trying a different path (not that are many, the levels are very linear) means more time wasted walking around.

EDIT: I totally agree with TotalBiscuit, I had the same feelings as him while playing Dear Esther. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=--LmQrsD6b0

reviewText: While Dear Esther isn't for everyone, I believe that it is a beautiful experience. Instead of looking at it as a game with a specific objective, look and judge it as a piece of art. Even though I love Dear Esther now, when I first began to play it I was incredibly bored. The reason for that is because I didn't understand that this was more of a poem/story with visuals rather than a normal game. If you really enjoy obscure, out-of-the-ordinary games with beautiful visuals, play Dear Esther. If not, then do not buy it. (Also as a plus, the game's soundtrack is breathtaking.)
