reviewText:
It has been over 3 years since the last time I played, and all I can tell is that all this time whenever someone asked me for a special game, this one always came up on the list.

3 years later it still feels special, and as my english improved I got bits of the story that I didn't get on the previous playthroughs

Recommended for everyone(except if you are suffering from severe depression, obviously). You might like it or not, you might get bored at the first 5 minutes or you might remember it forever as a special experience

I personally like to play it at night, with headphones and the lights off, it lasts around 1 hour, depending on how much time you spend exploring

reviewText:
I have to admit that at first I hated this.  So much so that I uninstalled it and never gave it another thought.  Then I read a review where someone said they hated it, but they gave it antoher try.  Yes, the game is different than anything I've played before.  I have nothing to compare it to at all.  All I can say is that it does take a bit to get into it, so don't write it off.

I will say the only thing I disliked is the fact I couldn't run.  When I go off exploring I would have liked to have been able to run back to where I left off instead of being penalized with a slow trod back.  I found myself hitting up youtube to save myself some time instead of exploring due to not wanting to break up the story by going the wrong way.

Aside from that, the music is amazing.  The scenery is stunning.  The story is.... well, I'll let you discover the story on your own.

reviewText: Great game, but ill give you some advices. Although it's a beatiful 'game'  with lots of symbolisms and a great design, it might be really unnerving to some people ( including myself), due to the solitude you may experience, it might even be a little 'depressing'. It's not a gory or tangible fear, it's a fearn born by  the subjectives meanings you'll give to the technically and artistically aspects of the game. Also, try to investigate and understand each single part of the island that you are allowed to roam, cause it will add more sense to the story you'll be creating.\nI wouldn't rate it, because I don't really consider it a game, but If I had to, AND ONLY JUDGING THE ARTISTICS ASPECTS, I would give it an 8/10.\n

reviewText: People have told me that this is a breakthrough in video game storytelling. Honestly, I find that incredibly insulting. Fallout, Planescape Torment, Chrono Trigger... These are what I consider prime examples of storytelling in video games. Something that takes the player into account, where not only are you the center of the game's world, you also have a say in its fate. Good interactive storytelling is just that; interactive. It should take advantage of the medium the author chose and how much potential it has to make something truly unique and expansive. Dear Esther squanders this in almost every way. It is a brief, bland episode of nothing but walking down a narrow pathway, observing the static environment as the author reads aloud his bad poetry. And yes, the poetry itself is bad, at least I think it is. If you think Dear Esther is good poetry, that's fine. I won't think any less of you for it. Just don't call it a good video game. It isn't one.

reviewText: This is a beautiful game that keeps you thinking and wondering till the end, as you explore the island you learn about a story about a couple and their journey together. There is no shooting or puzzles be had, there is nothing that is really a challenge in this game, all you do is explore and enjoy the scenery that is around you. The graphics and physics of the plants and movement of the water is amazing and very well done. The music is relaxing and peaceful to listen to. The story is captivation and makes you want to know more. The game of Dear Esther has a very nice pace to it. It is calming and doesn't take long at all to beat. I highly recommend this gem to anyone who wants a change of pace and wants to just walk around and look at things while hearing a story. This is a great game and I've really enjoyed it from beginning to end.

reviewText: Dear Esther was an interesting art project and not muxh else. There is no real gameplay to speak of other than walking through the world itself (at a snails pace I might add), waiting to hear nonlinear pieces of the plot.  It's short at about only an hours length, though you might be able to get a little more out of it by exploring every nook and cranny. Though there is no reason or incentive to do so as there is nothing to collect or achieve other than hearing other small snipets of the story.  And even that is diminished by fact that the story itself is simply not that engaging or interesting.  Overall, Esther has many interesting components but  ultimately fails to bring them together into a meanful experience.

reviewText:
In Dear Esther you play a man stranded on a island and your goal is to walk along this island and discover it's origin and the past of your character/the narrator. While the optics, the narrator and sound are pretty decent, the gameplay itself is rather boring. You wander around very slowly, may take a closer look at things and swim. From time to time the narrator tells you something. The whole thing is very linear and more than once you will stumble upon (invisible) borders where you can't go further, so in fact it is not so much about exploring but more about following a path.

I can see how people may like this game for being so different. However I think for enjoying this game you have to be really indie and highly intelectual on a philosophical level or so. For me this game was just 1.5h of boredom. I definetly wouldnt buy this game for the full price of 8€. And if I did so I would be pretty upset right now. Since I bought it at a sale I'm okay with it.

As a short story with some more background information and less wandering around, I might actually have liked this, but as a game" I would not recommend this."

reviewText:
This 'game' is more an excercise in design on both a graphical and musical level than it is in terms of gameplay or narrative writing. Most people laud it for the simple fact that its different, but being different alone should be justification for praise, you should also be good at what you are attempting to do and Dear Esther isn't.

It is the videogame equivilent of a pop-up book in the world in literature. You are taking down a linear path with some interactive parts jumping out at your but with very little else going on. The story isn't compelling, the characters uninteresting and the entire focus of the narrative just stale. This is most definately a matter of taste, but there are clear examples where a game that is mostly attempting to be a discussion or exploration is actually good. That example being the Stanely Parable.

One last note, the nail in the coffin in my opinion is this game's price. The entire experience clocks in at under an hour and for ten dollars that really isn't worth it. A more detailed exploration about the can be found on my blog here: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2013/03/dear-esther.html.

reviewText:
I was not engaged by the story, the most raved-about aspect of this game. The narrator has a fine voice, and delivers his lines well, but all too often the lines themselves are pompous and intentionally confusing.

The game doesn't confine itself to normal rules, but offers you a chance to explore as you like. The trouble is, exploring takes far too long. Not being able to run or jump may serve an ultimate purpose, but I found it to be detrimental to exploring the island. Numerous times I wondered what was around a corner or up a hill, only to realise that invisible walls or faulty polygon detection would get in my way halfway through the journey and I'd give up.

I do not have a problem with the length of the game in comparison to the price. However, I expect the emotional impact to be that much more potent. This did not deliver anything close to an impact.

I would not recommend this game, but would definitely be interested in the developer's second attempt at a game.

reviewText:
I cannot recommend this game. Do not get it unless it is less than $3. The first and second map (the beach with disgusting grungy human made stuff) are not too good, but I really loved the third map, the caves. They are really nicely made, and are a very spectacular sight to see. I did not appreciate the English writing in the caves, but the symbols were very cool. I really enjoyed that map. The fourth map is somewhat pretty, but not too spectacular. It's a beautiful nighttime view of the sea, but is corrupted by a few grungy human-made things, like a bunker, candles, etc. It also has the radio tower, which I did like, and the game ends in a nice flythrough of that scene (apparently from the shadow, you turn into a bird).
I'm left with a few questions, like why wax candles are still burning when I walk through, and why paper boats haven't sunk yet.

The gameplay is awful, if not completely non-existent. The game consists 100% entirely of walking. You can't interact with objects, like picking them up. You just walk. A lot. Really slowly. You can't sprint. You can't crouch. You can't even jump!

Not to be too mean to the graphics, as they are great in the last two maps, but they are not too good otherwise. All the plants are just 2D planes that follow you around, and turn to follow you, which is unrealistic. In addition, texture quality is not too great (at max settings). Textures are often skewed and stretched, and seams are sometimes visible. Much more detail could be done on the models. The water is very pretty, and looks pretty good. I like it.

The music is also nice in most parts, thought he narration is nowhere near good. Don't get me wrong, the voice acting is VERY good, but the fragmented poem he reads makes little sense, and hurts the gameplay. I am still not sure who Ester is... Me? Another person in the past? Someone in a journal? I am also not sure who the narrator is... Me? Another person in the past? Someone in a journal? Nobody in particular? The island itself? The content of the narration is also very mysterious and mood-breaking. In the middle of beautiful scenery, it speaks of a car crash and a drunk driver. I love the voice acting, but the content is just... bad. I would even like to disable narration, but this is not possible.

Finally, the game is very short. I beat it first time in just over an hour. I thought I was going to play it real quickly to see what it's like, and to my surprise, I had beaten the game just when I was thinking of getting off.

There is also no way to save the game, so you must play each map from start to finish (which isn't exactly hard, since each map is so short). You can select each separate map from the menu screen.

All in all, it's a good play at interactive storytelling, but it could be done much better. It is very short, and some of its maps are not great, while others are spectacular. I enjoyed the experience, but am not satisfied with the $5 I spent on it (on sale). Models and textures are not the greatest quality, but the environment design and technology behind the game is very good. There is not story that can be easily followed, and the narration makes little sense, and its content breaks the mood. The voice acting itself is of very high quality, though. The gameplay is really bad, as you cannot run, jump, or pick things up. You are confined only to slow walking, and nothing else. Finally, the game is very short. I would rate it 2 of 5 stars, being an interesting experiment, which may be possible to grow into something better in a future game, but this is not too good by itself. Some spectacular caves, I must say, as well as good music, but I can not recommend anyone gets this game, even for $5.

reviewText:
I got this game because I had heard complaints that it was more of an interactive novel than a game. That kind of thing is right up my alley - it's the story I'm interested in. I had also seen some of the beautiful screen shots, and was eager to explore this little world.

I was disappointed by both the story and the exploration. The world is, indeed, beautiful, and there are details like crushed cigarette packages on the ground and flowers waving in the breeze. The problem is that there isn't much more to it than what you can see in the trailer. After you've had a good look at the shack by the lighthouse and its surroundings, there's nothing new to see until you get to the caves. The caves are gorgeous, but again, once you've seen the first one, they all look more or less the same.

And there is no real exploration. You really are just playing a story, and the railroad tracks are firmly installed. Now and then it might appear that you have a choice to make, but you don't. There's always only one way you can go - split paths always quickly meet back up again.

The narrative is very poetic, often beautiful, sometimes touching. But there just isn't very much of it. The game description claims the audio, visuals, and events" (not sure what events they refer to) are randomly generated
date: but I played through twice and they didn't seem to be. There was some slight variation in the order that you hear the various fragments of text
recommended: but not enough that I'd call it "random." Once you've played it through once
hoursPlayed: which takes about an hour
voteText: maybe 90 minutes if you really take your time and poke around a lot

votesTotal: it loses most of its emotional effect. I suppose if you have some personal connection to the event in question

reviewText: I am, of course, an advocate for games as an art medium. Video games can very well be the epitome of art, and display different ways of expressing art. But I don't think I can call this game art. I cannot call this a game, because it is not. I realize it's a tired joke, but walking simulator" may very well be the exact definition this game pushes for. It lacks gameplay elements
recommended: it lacks any sort of... well
hoursPlayed: "fun." I believe fun to be a very central philosophy to follow when designing a video game
voteText: no matter what sort of game it is. Likewise
helpfulPercent: games can be both art and fun at the same time
votesHelpful: contradicting those who believe fun must be sacrified for the good of art. Deus Ex. Half Life. Portal. Fallout. These are games that offer the player a chance to enjoy its mechanics and immerse themselves in an interesting story and atmosphere whilst treating the player with the most basic function: fun. It is fun to sneak past or gun down your adversaries in an attempt to unveil conspiracies in Deus Ex. But while you do so
votesTotal: you become immersed in a deep plot that questions your motif
votesFunny: your resolve
commentsCount: and it completely conveys the meaning of art. Dear Esther cannot accomplish this

reviewText:
I have never, ever, never taken the time to stop and review a Steam game. Ever. After investing some time in this title, I felt the need to take time out of my hectic schedule to stop and comment on how exactly this game has changed my life.

If you've played all the classic environmental/atmospheric games like Mist, 7th Guest, 11th Hour, Amnesia, and the like: don't play this title. I get it, the author is trying to be the black sheep; the yin to the yang of every day Steam titles. Sadly, this is an utter dissapointment. I am completely disgusted at the poor attempt that this game makes at standing out as a dynamic novel packaged in an immersing video game setting. I really wish there was something that made this title compelling or at the very least tolerable but there is not.

Fortunately I got this during a Steam sale, otherwise I would petition my money back. Not even Esther herself could appreciate this atrocity. If you want a sub-par audio book, sign up for an account at Audible.com. There's no reason that you should bother spending your hard earned dosh on filth such as this.

Do yourself a favor, purchase Telltale Game's The Walking Dead" or "The Wolf Among Us" and be content with your purchase on Steam. Otherwise
date: if you purchase this title I look forward to your synopsis; your plea to prevent any other poor souls from wasting their funds on this trash. Dear Esther? Meh

reviewText:
I bought this game knowing full well there would not be much in the way of gameplay. I knew this would be more an interactive story than a game and that's fine. I really enjoyed Gone Home" - another interactive story of sorts - so I thgouht I might enjoy this too. I was wrong.

The only interactivity of any sort is slowly pacing along a set linear route while a voice speaks to you. I would love to be more clear but the plot was so stuffy I was left not knowing what really happened. The heavy use of metaphors sometimes made the plot feel a little streched thin over the time period and also helped to confuse me greatly as to what the speaker was actually on about. Sometimes it just felt like the writer was trying to get the most value for money from their newly bought thesaurus.

On the plus side the soudtrack is quite nice and the scenery was at times beautiful.

Pros:
-cheap
-beautiful setting
-soundtrack

Cons:
-Story is too stuffy/wordy
-walk incredibly slowly
-barely qualifies as interactive"

reviewText:
Dear Esther.

Please don't make such a pretentious game under the guise that you're creating art, you can only hide a lackluster story with pretty environments and garbled nonsensical dialogue that reads like baby first poetry.

As I type this every keystroke thundered into the empty void of my heart, the melancholy locale only invigured the pestilence stirring within my bowels. A glint of hope dispelled through the very caverns of my mind as the waves crashed endlessly upon the boundaries of linear exploration.

This is you.

You sound like a ♥♥♥♥.

yours sincerely,

Mooshman.

reviewText: A jaw-dropping visual experience that's sadly wasted by an extremely disappointing storyline followed by a catastrophically pretentious and insubstantial ending that lacks any real meaning. If you're looking for a good philosophical adventure with elements of exploration and discovery, I recommend you completely ignore Dear Esther and instead play something like The Stanley Parable or Alan Wake.\n\nThe gameplay" of Dear Esther (for me) went from a giddy awe-inspiring exploration
date: seeking clues and adventure within an incredibly immersive environment full of realistic atmospheric soundscapes
recommended: but slowly transforms into a tedious illusion limited by frustratingly erroneous boundaries compounded by the inability to run or jump or interact with anything.\n\nThere was allot of potential for this to be an amazing experience that rewards exploration with a genuine philosophical mind-bending story
hoursPlayed: but I was sadly left with an abysmally hollow sinking experience made infinitely worse by a lackluster storyline and ending
voteText: which somehow manages to get even worse by drowning persistence and curiosity with a black screen that perpetually does nothing and goes nowhere."

reviewText:
This 'game' is more an excercise in design on both a graphical and musical level than it is in terms of gameplay or narrative writing. Most people laud it for the simple fact that its different, but being different alone should be justification for praise, you should also be good at what you are attempting to do and Dear Esther isn't.

It is the videogame equivilent of a pop-up book in the world in literature. You are taking down a linear path with some interactive parts jumping out at your but with very little else going on. The story isn't compelling, the characters uninteresting and the entire focus of the narrative just stale. This is most definately a matter of taste, but there are clear examples where a game that is mostly attempting to be a discussion or exploration is actually good. That example being the Stanely Parable.

One last note, the nail in the coffin in my opinion is this game's price. The entire experience clocks in at under an hour and for ten dollars that really isn't worth it. A more detailed exploration about the can be found on my blog here: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2013/03/dear-esther.html.

reviewText: When I went into this game, I knew that it had little to no gameplay, as if it was an interactive movie. That's ok I thought, it will tell a good story using the possibility of a game as a storytelling medium.\nNo, it didn't. I finished the game and I have no idea who the protagonist is, who this Esther is nor what that damn island is. You just spend an hour walking SLOWLY without knowing what to do.\nMaybe I'm just dumb and I didn't get what the game was about, but as far as I can tell this game is absolutely useless.

reviewText:
I was not engaged by the story, the most raved-about aspect of this game. The narrator has a fine voice, and delivers his lines well, but all too often the lines themselves are pompous and intentionally confusing.

The game doesn't confine itself to normal rules, but offers you a chance to explore as you like. The trouble is, exploring takes far too long. Not being able to run or jump may serve an ultimate purpose, but I found it to be detrimental to exploring the island. Numerous times I wondered what was around a corner or up a hill, only to realise that invisible walls or faulty polygon detection would get in my way halfway through the journey and I'd give up.

I do not have a problem with the length of the game in comparison to the price. However, I expect the emotional impact to be that much more potent. This did not deliver anything close to an impact.

I would not recommend this game, but would definitely be interested in the developer's second attempt at a game.

reviewText: Dear Esther is the kind of game you play entirely in one sitting, that feels short and that makes you question what you just experienced, but that leaves a giant mark on your appreciation of passive narratives and video games as an art form.\n\nIn a way, each playthrough is different, as some parts of the story are chosen at random between a pool of possible happenings, but the core of the story stays the same in all playthroughs, which kind of make you want to play again and again to see what the other elements of the story end up adding to your understanding of what happened. The entire time the way you're supposed to go is fairly obvious, but at some points you have to explore a bit to know where to go. hile I'm not really a fan of linear paths

reviewText:
This isn't a game so much as an interactive work of art.

The only thing you can do is walk around looking at things while you listen to the narrative. It's like walking around inside an audio book. The movement speed is frustratingly slow unless you hack the ini files (which you should).

The story is very good and emotionally gripping. You won't hear the whole thing on a single playthrough. Each playthrough tells random snippets of the story, and the game leaves you to piece together the rest. This makes for fun conversations when you discuss the plot with your friends but there's not enough variety for more than a couple replays.

Game length is about an hour, but there's enough content to stretch that out to two hours through a second replay. Worth playing for the novelty - there's not much else out there like this.

reviewText: Great game, but ill give you some advices. Although it's a beatiful 'game'  with lots of symbolisms and a great design, it might be really unnerving to some people ( including myself), due to the solitude you may experience, it might even be a little 'depressing'. It's not a gory or tangible fear, it's a fearn born by  the subjectives meanings you'll give to the technically and artistically aspects of the game. Also, try to investigate and understand each single part of the island that you are allowed to roam, cause it will add more sense to the story you'll be creating.\nI wouldn't rate it, because I don't really consider it a game, but If I had to, AND ONLY JUDGING THE ARTISTICS ASPECTS, I would give it an 8/10.\n

reviewText:
I could (and have done numerous times in the past) rant for hours about this game. The most pretentious attempt at a story driven indie game 'experience' I've ever seen.

In fact I'm pretty sure they just took a 14 year olds B+ graded English poetry essay and had it read aloud to you very slowly as you're forced to walk around in a dismal, repetitive island made in the Source engine.

I understand how for some people who like to do everything they can to find meaningful messages in absolutely everything even when there aren't any, this game must be a joy but I just can't say I feel the same way.

reviewText:
This is a tough game for me to recommmend, would love it there was a 'Neutral' button on Steam. It's beautiful and the music is amazing, but the game feels shallow. The ending is nice, but it comes after slowly walking for 90+ minutes.

The last chapter feels most enjoyable, I'm not sure who would want to play through the first two though to get to that point honestly.

Suggestions for improvement

- Keep the user engaged more consistently through the narrartion. More talking, even if it's minor thoughts.
- Interactions. Something to feel like you're actually engaged in the world
- Make it more linear, if the point is pushing the story forward and the are no 'Easter Eggs' or 'rewards' for exploring make it so someone can't 'Get Lost'
- Subtitles - Could be more interesting, could be used as typograhic art that scrolls or changes in size and font to fit the mood. They felt drab and did little for immersion, so I turned them off
- Abilty to walk faster...jog even. Less of an issue if it was more linear, but going 'The wrong Way' then back tracking is tiresome here
- Camera: Make more dynamic, small bobbing as the character walks

reviewText: I honestly tried to admire this game on its own terms, but I can't help feeling like there's not that much to admire in Dear Esther. I like the idea of a game where the game-like part is a minor pathfinding exercise, and you're free to look and listen to everything else, and the narration is all worldbuilding, but... this implementation of the idea isn't magical. Still, I should recommend it, since it produced a very different effect on different people.

reviewText: I'm torn with this...game. As other reviewers have stated, it's not really a game. For me it was more an experience. The music is wonderful and adds perfectly to the atmosphere. There were moments on the journey that I was lost in this other world. When I looked up from my computer I was back in my crummy apartment.\nIt wasn't until the final chapter that I really had a problem. I fell into the water and my game froze, though the sound kept going. Normally you would just be brought back but I never was. I exited to the menu to start from the final chapter and it wouldn't let me. In fact, it would only select the first chapter. Really? I spent all that time and I can't even finish it!?\nSo wonderful experience but that fatal flaw just didn't make it worthwhile in the end.

What can I say about this game? Well a lot actually. when you start the game you think hmmm this seems like it my be some kind of horror game. Better watch my back. As you SLOWLY progress through the game you realize its not. now when I say slowly if you couldn't tell I meant it in the whole sense of the word. Your character walks like like a sloth through tar and you cant run or pick up stuff or solve puzzles because the only controls are WASD and the mouse to look around. Thats it there are no other controls to the game. So If you thought that this might be some kind of mist tribute like some people I know you are sadly mistaken and I am so glad that I could stop them from buying this game just like I'm trying to convince you to do. But I digress. So back to the actuall game. It runs off of the valve source engine so you can expect what kind of graphics to see in the game only they are about 2X worse some how. The game is very slow, very boring, and very pointless. It shouldn't even be considered a game for crying out loud. Also he talks some other random crap I was to bored to care about. So as you walk through the game you reach this raido tower where he talks about Ester some more and how he hurt her. Then..... are you ready for this? He jumps off and Kills him self. Then its game over. there is no new game plus there is nothing interesting that happens after the credits... its just over. You killed your self. Thats it.


In short what do I think of this game. Its crap in its purest form. If you took a machine that could convert crap into computer data that data would come out to be this game. Is boring, unintersting and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. (and no I will not apologize for using the R word because this is America and I'm intitled to say what ever I want.)

DO NOT! I REPEAT! DO NOT BUY THIS GAME! IT IS IN NO WAY EVER GOING TO BE WORTH THE TIME OR MONEY

I'm just so glad I got it in a humble bundle so I only spent about $2 on this and like 4 other games because if I had spent the whole $9.99 they are asking for I probably would have driven down to the studio my self and demanded the money back from the person in charge of making this game him/her self.

reviewText: Dear Esther is, quite simply, the most beautiful and moving game I have ever played. You can feel the bitter ocean wind from the moment you step on the island. Every step of the journey is masterfully detailed and filled with the depressing personality of the island. The story may be confusing at first, but it's overwhelming and engrossing. The music is brilliant, and the caves are beautiful. The story snippets are also randomized, and there's an alternate ending, so be sure to play it more than once.

A beautiful game filled with sights and sounds to please. The audio is incredible and the world is crafted with precision. The story is intriguing, if vague. However, I wasn't in it for the story. I loved the game just to walk through it, as a walking simulator should be.
If you've never tried walking before this is the way to experience a great walk to peak your interest. Or, if you just haven't moved from your seat to walk in a long time, this is the way to walk without exertion. Try this walk on your computer screen, you wont be disappointed.

Genuinely highly recommended.

reviewText: Dear Esther is an excellent demonstration of the immersive storytelling virtual worlds can achieve. It combines magnificent visuals, a subtle, yet powerful soundtrack and stellar voice acting to tell a very touching story that explores darker themes like regret, grief and loneliness. It does so with a certain ambiguity which leaves one to ponder and theorize about the meaning of what has been witnessed long after the end. It is an impressive experience, but one I imagine not everyone can enjoy.

reviewText:
Dear Esther: You either get it or you don't, there doesn't seem to be a middle ground with Chinese Room's island tour. Look it up on Metacritics, you'll know what I mean.

It's not long, you can finish it in about 90 minutes or so.

reviewText:
Hauntingly beautiful and incredibly engrossing, Dear Esther from thechineseroom is a unique experience that combines sound, storytelling, and mystery to immerse the player in a disturbing world. Not scary by Doom 3 or Amnesia standards, everything creepy about this game takes place in the unreliable narrator's head. This style of narrative gaming takes the player on a spiritual journey from start to finish and makes Dear Esther worth at least one playthrough; the breathtaking world building, artistic style, and semi-random narrative fragments just might make it worth a few more to those who really want to piece the story and world together.  That said, if you're looking for concrete answers, this game doesn't have them, it only contains more questions - that's part of its beauty.

Pros:

Unique, narrative gaming experience
Immersive
Beautiful music and setting
Wonderful level design (the cave is amazing)
Settings are comprehensive yet not overwhelming, including adjustable field of view was a nice touch
Because of its styling, every gamer will take a different story away from this game. A different point of view on the events that transpired in the narrator's past. I find that amazing, and that's why this game is so worthwhile.

Cons:

No action, everything takes place in gamer's head
Walk speed is a little slow

Definitely worth a playthrough. While not a game in the traditional sense this blend of artistic narrative and interactive storytelling is well done and quite a unique experience. There is a free mod available (which I've played) but the updated graphics and world building in the official game make it definitely the better of the two and I would highly recommend simply skipping the mod and playing the stand-alone game first. B+

To explore here is to become passive
date: to internalise the journey and not to attempt to break the confines...It will take a number of expeditions to traverse this microcontinent; it will take the death of a million neurons
hoursPlayed: countless service stations and bypasses to arrive at the point of final departure.""

I'm not entirely certian what is going on in this game.

It does present a very excellently crafted landscape to explore.  I have read some people believe this to be an amazing story, but it's lost on me.  I have a hard time appreciating figurative works.  I understand the main story branch, but all the symbolism makes no sense to me.  It was like I was in high school english all over again.  I wonder if there are Dear Esther Cliff Notes?

If you enjoy figurative works and have an hour to invest, pick this up.  Otherwise stay away.

reviewText:
Dear Esther is an interesting beast. To get it out in the open at first opportunity, I don't really care for Esther, but that doesn't mean it's completely inconsequential.

First things first; this game is beautiful. The modeling isn't the best ever, and it's rendered in Source so it looks distractingly like Half-Life 2, but there are some moments that frankly left me in awe from spectacle alone. There's also an admirable attention to detail, seeing shadowy figures on mountaintops or in reflections, things that really add to the atmosphere. And for the record, the ending, while being probably very pretentious, was incredibly well-executed and made me feel an emotion I couldn't quite identify upon viewing.

But in the end, this game is marred by its attempts to become anything more than a walking simulator. I've never really cared for these, because they don't offer anything a video or movie couldn't do better, but Esther tries to step around that by throwing a wrench into the formula; the story, displayed in the form of voiceovers, is randomly switched around and chopped up. While it was probably intended for artistic reasons and to build intrigue, all it ends up doing is making the (fairly good) story completely impenetrable and difficult to understand upon a first playthrough. Thus, all meaning of the story is lost, and without context all that is left is a pretty face with nothing backing it up.

reviewText:
Dear Esther is an aesthically pleasing, story-rich experience that is thoughtful, beautiful, and intriguing. It's not something that everyone is going to enjoy, as it is less a game and more of an exploratory journey used to deliver a narrative. The term 'walking-simulator' has been dealt out to ths particular genre of games and, while I don't really think that term is useful, it does attempt to give define a tag to apply to these games that offer its players more than just a wandering quest to complete. What Dear Esther offers its players is a contemplative work of art that left me thinking about the game for a few hours after completing it. It's graphics, voice-work, music, and writing all colate into a fine design that is worth taking your time to experience.

I think that if I played too many of these games too often, or consecutively, I would grow tired of the genre as a whole, but they are something that I enjoy partaking in on occasion, and it's the same enjoyment that I find in reading a good book. The player awakes on an island and is left to their own devices to explore though there is a 'correct' path that will reveal more of the narrative. There are some interesting hidden elements in the game that are quite creepy, and the package as a whole is very well done.

I'd recommend this game for those who want to enjoy an interesting and well told story within the interactive medium of a game. You won't find challenges, or riddles, or enemies to overcome, only a story that you can walk around inside at your leisure, discern yourself, and leave you to contemplate afterwards.

reviewText: This isn't a full fledged game review as I haven't finished it yet (and I'm not sure if I ever will), but after completing Anna Extended Edition, I guess I was expecting a bit more from Dear Esther. It's literally a walking simulator with some narrated stuff that doesn't seem to have much in relation to the scenery itself. Granted, the scenery is amazing, calling it just breathtaking would be an understatement, especially since it's running on somewhat dated Source Engine. But paying 9,99€ for a game" with pretty scenery where all (and only thing) you can do is walk around stupendously slowly is simply not worth it. I got it through a cheap deal so it's not that big of a deal

reviewText:
As much as people hype up this game, I can't reccommend it. It has some interesting aspects and interesting points to think about, but is it a good 'game'? Eh.

TLDR is at the bottome /

Dear Esther is a game where you walk around and explore. . . sorta. As you walk around, little tid bits of who you are (or might be/just a narrator) pop up and give you a vague idea of the story in the form of letters. Well, read aloud letters. It's pretty neat how the story bits can tie in with what you are spectating. However, exploring can get pretty tedious. If you don't walk into a certain area you don't get the dialogue, or if you back track you don't get anything. Since you can't run, there can be long pauses where it's just you walking around trying to figure out where you should go. There are paths that lead you to and fro with a few other paths leading to new bits of dialogue, but attempting to explore much can lead to lots of boring backtracking through large areas. Going as linear as you can is probably more enjoyable.

As far as environments go, Dear Esther has some gorgeous locations. The whole 'game' takes place on a small uninhabitated island, so you're gonna get a lot of ocean and some pretty cool caves to. . . well, walk through. I was particularly impressed with the caves and are by far my favorite part of the game.

And the narrative. If you haven't heard anything about Dear Esther, be warned - It can get confusing. Each run can give you slightly different audio tidbits. Last time I checked, some of them lead to very different assumptions on what the story actually is/means. That means with each playthrough, every person might hear slightly different things. That by no means makes this replayable though. There is NO replayability in this game unless you desperately want to see what differences you can get. The enviroments don't change, trecking through each area is a bore after awhile, and the ending does not change. This game is only WALKING and LISTENING to dialogue. I swear if you replay Dear Esther, you have to either be crazy or a dedicated Wiki editor.

TLDR; Dear Esther is an interesting take on narrative, but the long stretches between that narrative, ruthless lack of nothing if you dare go off the linear path and explore (expect a few meaningless narrative tidbits), and lack of replayability make this a less than par experiance.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying this is not a game. This is something more akin to an interactive poem as you explore a solitary island and come to terms with the grave tragedy that befell you and your loved one.

A beautiful landscape and background musics sets the atmosphere for your journey as passages from a diary or book of sorts are narrated with heartfelt sentiment. In a nutshell, an emotional portrayal of the impact of loss and the search for peace.

I definitely recommend giving this a try if you're into philosophical, self-reflection, poetic and emotional thinking and do not mind spending 1 or 2 hours wandering around, listening to the narration, piecing together what happened and reflecting about the particularities of life. I certainly found it relaxing.

reviewText:
I enjoy interactive narratives like Thirty Flights of Loving, Dys4ia, Passage, Stanley Parable, (I'll even defend the much hated Dinner Date) but I really, really did not enjoy Dear Esther.

The main problem I have with it is that I don't feel like my interaction is vital or adds anything to the offered experience. Yes, I can walk around and enjoy the level design on my own terms but how is this reflexive of any sort of narrative theme. Yes, narrative elements are implemented into the environment, and vice-versa, but if this game were on rails with the player only controlling the direction the camera was facing and the speed of progression would the experience really be that different?

If I don't feel like my interaction is important, that it is necessary for me to be a participant, then I might as well be a bystander and observer, in which case this is not the proper medium for the piece. If you're going to make something interactive, it needs to be interactive for a reason.

reviewText:
Beautiful game. Absolutely beautiful prose, narration, music, art. If you like literature or are even vaguely artsy, I want you to play this because not enough people understand how beautiful it is. Complex, rich parallel storyline that can be interpreted both figuratively and literally.

~English major intensifies~
Not really an English major... but seriously. It's a work of art, and of the highest quality too. If this was a book, it'd be my favorite book. But it's not, because it's meant to be that way, and it's beautiful that way. The narration, the vagueness, the art -- the interaction of music, visual art and story is what makes Dear Esther great. Really, it's all the beautiful complexity of literature... made interactive.

I'd wish for more like it, but I don't see how prose that beautiful can be recreated or surpassed.

Sorry. I felt the need to rewrite this review after Steam evidently erased it. This is one of my all-time favorite gifts.

reviewText:
Dear Esther was a title I followed quite closely the minute I had set eyes upon it (this review is quite horridly delayed in it's making and I apologize). It's incredible visuals had me drawn to seeing what it brought to the table, and sadly, it falls into a style of game that will constantly be picked on and labelled, pretentious, trying too hard or as a simple walking simulator. All of this could not be further from the truth. This is the kind of atmospheric game that has to be experienced and sampled. It is not for everyone, and that is completely fine. If lack of game-play makes something bad for you, steer clear of this.

The storyline been a bit hazy, is actually done in such a way that makes it powerful and one of it's best qualities. The story conveys itself in a series of audio messages of a person who ended up on this uninhabited Hebridean island, listening to a series of voiced-over letter fragments to a woman named Esther. The narrator's identity is not specified, (Personally his voice reminded me of Richard Burton) though there are many suggestions that he is Esther's husband and that she died in a tragic car accident. He constantly references Esther, Paul, Donnelly and Jakobson and as you continue on it becomes more blurred as the game progresses, the narration moves between topics and relates the characters in different ways. The random selection of voice-over parts causes ambiguity opens up a lot of doors for the player to draw their own conclusions of the how this story ends up playing out.

My take on the story is that this un-named protagonist lost all of his companions after somehow ending up on this island, some to infections they simply could not heal, some committed suicide, and some failed at escaping. It's unknown as to who or how many people were there previously, as the structures around the place lead me to conclude that this has happened before or that the people that were constantly refered back to made all of them. The last living piece of the puzzle is Esters husband.. Perhaps he had slowly gone mad and gone to the top of the aerial to kill himself and join his fallen friends.

Moving on from that however.. The scenery and the music create such an incredible peaceful feeling. The environment draws you to it with it's beauty, making you stop just to admire it, or at least it did with me. I love the entire feel of this game as a whole, it's something new that we have not seen, forming art into a playable immersive form to lose yourself within your alone time, encompassing you in something you want to go from beginning to end.

With it being semi-randomly generated, it does offer replay value of 2+ hours, making passes to places you may have missed before and in doing so end up finding more hidden dialogue as well. The opposing bit to that is that this only offers a max 3 hours of play, is sadly very short, but that by no means makes it bad. It is more of a story than an actual game as it offers nothing interact-able, other than just walking, listening and enjoying the land in which you travel across to get to the end.

I wholeheartedly recommend this to anyone who enjoys simply.. enjoying art, story and a stunning environment in which to do that in.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Dear Esther isn't much of a game, there's no challenge or goals involved. All you do is press forward. Literally.

That being said, it's only the surface of things. Dear Esther manages to pull off one thing a good game is supposed to have: the atmosphere and it does that so well. The abandoned island reeks with melancholy and it certainly makes you ponder. There were times I could almost feel the wind hitting my face, it's quite an amazing experience in that regard. The tranquility of the island is further amplified by a beautiful sound track by Jessica Curry, I've slept listening to it numerous times. While the occasional dialogue makes little to no sense as a whole, that doesn't by the least bit turn me off from the experience, rather it makes the experience all the more intense, thanks to the terrific voice over work.

Considering it is lacking a lot of fundamental characterisitcs of a videogame, it still remains to be one of the best experiences I've had. To put it in perspective, I have replayed that 4 times so far just so I could get some alone time, where as I can mention a bunch of actual games in my library which I've left without even playing them for an hour, let alone completing them. Moreover, I certainly see myself getting back to it yet again, Oculus Rift support would make that all the more tempting. I've certainly become a fan of Chinese Room after this so I'm looking forward to checking out Everybody's Gone to Rapture.

reviewText:
Well, is this a game? If so, is it worth playing?

To be honest: I don't know. Is it groundbreaking...I don't think so.
Yes, it is a very nice way to tell a story, the grafics are very nice, the caverns are astonishingly beautiful, then again we are talking about a static world here, so it should look nice. The audio is spot on most of the time, the music, especially the piano is great.
The narrator is just awesome.

Unfortunately the story he tells is not. Basically Dear Esther is as if someone tells you a story and you can look around in the story he tells you.
It is entirely linear, one has no option of interacting with the world whatsoever.
It is intriguing and creates a nice atmosphere, but the story remains very very vague, nothing is explained, don't expect that some truth" is unraveled in the end.

Also I did not quite like the poetry-style of the narration

reviewText:
If you're thinking of buying this ''game'', ask yourself this question - Are you looking for a game? If you said yes, then don't buy Dear Esther.

This ''game'' lasts you 30-40 minutes (I have 53 minutes of ''play-time'' because I couldn't find the road at the start and was looking around for 10+ minutes.), it has no gameplay what so ever, but what it does have is good looking environments and a pleasant narrator. The whole story is read to you while you visit points of interest that go together with the story. If you're someone who enjoys sitting back and visiting museums with an audio-book talking in the background, then I think you'll enjoy Dear Esther. Or you might just enjoy listening to a good narrator read you a story (Which this narrator is, really good.). But if you're someone who's actually looking to play something. Then this isn't it for you.

reviewText: First off, the game is GORGEOUS. The only controls you have are walking and swimming up. You just walk through the island while a narrator reads letters to Esther. You don't pick up objects or interact with anything, you just walk around. Like I said, the game is gorgeous, so it is not really a bad thing to have to do. I wouldn't recommend this to everyone as it is not your typical type of game. And the story is pretty hard to follow your first time through. If you find it on sale for 1-2$ and would like to see an absolutely beautiful landscape, then I recommend checking it out.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying this is not a game. This is something more akin to an interactive poem as you explore a solitary island and come to terms with the grave tragedy that befell you and your loved one.

A beautiful landscape and background musics sets the atmosphere for your journey as passages from a diary or book of sorts are narrated with heartfelt sentiment. In a nutshell, an emotional portrayal of the impact of loss and the search for peace.

I definitely recommend giving this a try if you're into philosophical, self-reflection, poetic and emotional thinking and do not mind spending 1 or 2 hours wandering around, listening to the narration, piecing together what happened and reflecting about the particularities of life. I certainly found it relaxing.

reviewText: Is this a video game? Or is it a movie? Is it open-world, or do I just keep making the one, correct decision? Is it a horror game? Or am I just paranoid? Am I alone? Or are there others? Is this a drama? Or a thriller? Am I narrating my own actions, or are they the actions of another person? WHO AM I?! WHY AM I HERE?! WHERE IS HERE?! WHO IS ESTHER???!!!! - This game answers none of these questions, but is still ultimately fantastic. 10/10; it's like a movie for your mind that leaves you wanting more.

reviewText:
Right off the bat, this game is not a game, it's an experience. Or a walking simulator. The idea is you wake up on an island that may or may not actually exist as you travel to a beacon in the centre of the island because it's flashing red so why not.

If you're looking for a fun game to play turn the hell back because this game doesn't have any, you walk around listening to the monologue of the player character. The only motivation you have though is curiosity to try and figure out what happened, you won’t be saving the world from the combine or any ♥♥♥♥ like that here. I have to give it credit though, I was definitely interested enough to see it through to the end, which took me under one hour to reach so this is more of an interactive art thing than anything else.

Nothing in this game is set in stone though, you are left to interpret the events and things you see for yourself, so this game and its plot and meaning are entirely what you make of it. Also, many of the things you see in this game are different each time you play. Some stuff you see or hear may not be in other playthroughs so due to the purposefully fragmented and incoherency it forces you to guess for yourself what're really happening even more.

It can take up to 6-8 full runs in order to have seen every object and/or event at least once."

The graphics and environments are very pretty though and the soundtrack is nice and fitting
date: lots of stuff for you to see and wonder what the significant of this thing you're looking at is alright I found most of the writing on the cliff walls hard to read and often found myself not listening to half of what the character said because I was inspecting things I found and the 'ghosts'.\n\nIt's not a scary game in the slightest
recommended: it might be a bit eerie if you're a wuss

reviewText:
As much as people hype up this game, I can't reccommend it. It has some interesting aspects and interesting points to think about, but is it a good 'game'? Eh.

TLDR is at the bottome /

Dear Esther is a game where you walk around and explore. . . sorta. As you walk around, little tid bits of who you are (or might be/just a narrator) pop up and give you a vague idea of the story in the form of letters. Well, read aloud letters. It's pretty neat how the story bits can tie in with what you are spectating. However, exploring can get pretty tedious. If you don't walk into a certain area you don't get the dialogue, or if you back track you don't get anything. Since you can't run, there can be long pauses where it's just you walking around trying to figure out where you should go. There are paths that lead you to and fro with a few other paths leading to new bits of dialogue, but attempting to explore much can lead to lots of boring backtracking through large areas. Going as linear as you can is probably more enjoyable.

As far as environments go, Dear Esther has some gorgeous locations. The whole 'game' takes place on a small uninhabitated island, so you're gonna get a lot of ocean and some pretty cool caves to. . . well, walk through. I was particularly impressed with the caves and are by far my favorite part of the game.

And the narrative. If you haven't heard anything about Dear Esther, be warned - It can get confusing. Each run can give you slightly different audio tidbits. Last time I checked, some of them lead to very different assumptions on what the story actually is/means. That means with each playthrough, every person might hear slightly different things. That by no means makes this replayable though. There is NO replayability in this game unless you desperately want to see what differences you can get. The enviroments don't change, trecking through each area is a bore after awhile, and the ending does not change. This game is only WALKING and LISTENING to dialogue. I swear if you replay Dear Esther, you have to either be crazy or a dedicated Wiki editor.

TLDR; Dear Esther is an interesting take on narrative, but the long stretches between that narrative, ruthless lack of nothing if you dare go off the linear path and explore (expect a few meaningless narrative tidbits), and lack of replayability make this a less than par experiance.

reviewText:
This is not a game, but rather an attempt to create an effect akin to walking through poetry. The story is well written and holds depth beyond the surface explaination, the narration is exemplary, and the visuals are nothing short of phenominal.

If you are looking for an experience to inspire, or move you, this does it well, for those who can appreciate it in all its complexity.

But if you just want another game to play for mechanical interaction, this is not something you'll enjoy.

reviewText: Starting off as a humble source-mod in '08, and later evolving into a wonderful and visually stunning gameplay experience. Dear Esther is a thought-provoking poetic ghost story of sorts with a powerful narrative and beautiful scenery that push the source engine to it's full granduer while still keeping the system requirements at a reasonable standard. As your journey across the island continues questions will arise, who is this man giving you such a compelling story? Am I playing as him or the Esther, the game's namesake? Who is that translucent robed figure dissapearing behind the rocks? Eventually these question increase in depth, which I refuse to share here as it would spoil the experience.\nWhile it is slow-paced and has a replayability factor of 1 or 2 times, Dear Esther is highly compelling and should not be missed, unless you have the attention span of a gnat, in which case go chase butterflies.

reviewText: It's very hard to describe something which is not considered a game yet it claims to be one. Dear Esther brings up the whole discussion whether video games can be a form of art or not, I honestly believe I can but this case feels somewhat different for me. In Dear Esther the character you play as narrates an interesting and compeling story which comes with very great music, despite lacking most of the times. Not only that but you are able to witness some really beautifull landscapes and underground sections which probably were the most enjoying part for me. This leads to the a great question, is Dear Esther really a game? As far as I see it doesn't really offer any gameplay at all, you just walk around, it's basicly like watching a movie where you are the camera man per say. It's really hard for me to talk about these so called games" but yet I think that Dear Esther offers a great and wonderfull experience

reviewText:
I enjoy interactive narratives like Thirty Flights of Loving, Dys4ia, Passage, Stanley Parable, (I'll even defend the much hated Dinner Date) but I really, really did not enjoy Dear Esther.

The main problem I have with it is that I don't feel like my interaction is vital or adds anything to the offered experience. Yes, I can walk around and enjoy the level design on my own terms but how is this reflexive of any sort of narrative theme. Yes, narrative elements are implemented into the environment, and vice-versa, but if this game were on rails with the player only controlling the direction the camera was facing and the speed of progression would the experience really be that different?

If I don't feel like my interaction is important, that it is necessary for me to be a participant, then I might as well be a bystander and observer, in which case this is not the proper medium for the piece. If you're going to make something interactive, it needs to be interactive for a reason.

reviewText:
Graphics are really nice. Environment and 'feel' of the game is well done (albeit cold). Dialogue can be hard-to-follow and uninteresting at times, but the ending makes up for it I suppose.

If you are into eccentric indie games, than this is a more-or-less classic that you should try. Its short and worth the money in my opinon (even if only barely). Even better if you can get it on sale/in a bundle.

For those that are not typically into eccentric/artsy indies, keep in mind there is no 'game' here - only exploration.
